But in generally, we try not to do the incompatible changes.

Patch Set 3:> > (1 comment) > > > > So I did an initial review of the patch and I think the general > > concept is ok but I'm still not sure about some of the details. > > > > Mainly the use of -1 as special column index and having special > > cases for it everywhere. > > > > I'm not sure if we should not instead switch to a solution that > has > > a valid ScAttrArray for any ScColumn and if there is not yet a > > ScColumn inside of the ScTable we query the ScAttrArray stored in > > ScTable. I need to read more and talk to you, Eike and Kohei to > see > > what is the best solution. >  > Thanks for the review. >  > The ScAttrArray object (aNextColAttrArray) in the ScTable has its > nCol member set to -1 to indicate that it represents all > unallocated columns. The check nCol == -1 in ScAttrArray methods is > to prevent making calls to pDocument methods like InvalidateTextWidth() > from aNextColAttrArray as it requires a valid/existing Column. >  > The special cases in the ScAttrArray methods are in fact for the > case of default formatting where nCount == 0 and pData == nullptr.But do we actually call these methods for the default formatting? As far as I read the code the default formatting is stored in the ScTable instance. If these methods are supposed to be never called for the default formatting I think an assert is the better solution.Sorry that it currently takes me a bit longer to review patches. I'm quite busy with my thesis and can not afford to spend too much time on LibreOffice.

Patch Set 1:> Those vars are read without a mutex locked, > so dialogs can still be displayed multiple times.That's possible, but highly improbable (requires two UI (!) code paths to cross this in ~exactly same time), and I suppose that reading bool without lock is safe to prefer faster implementation to the one that has mutex overhead. > no, not unconditionally; each instance of JavaContext creates at > most one instance of JavaInteractionHandlerSorry, missed that. Will look further.

Patch Set 5:Thanks for the review ! Regression test added. It requires https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/30030 as well to pass. I double checked that it passes with both patches and fails without. Also rebased.

Patch Set 4:This is ready to review as far as I am concerned. All the tests passes (well, on my host, waiting for Jenkins opinion on this). To support sparse data list in a generic way, this patch fixes a couple of related bugs:- labels are parsed, created and stored at offset 0 but at some point changed to offset 1 in DataSequenceConverter::createDataSequence- the array parser in chart failed to parse empty cells (see other patch set)- fallback code for categories did not properly initialize aSeq.mnPointCount in TypeGroupConverter::createCategorySequenceI have been very careful to avoid side-cases, especially regarding the patch in chart2 BUT I'm quite new to this code base so...Let me know if you need my test pptx as well and how to provide it.

Patch Set 4:Looks good to me, thx!One important piece is missing though - could you please provide a unit test for the bugfix that:- fails without your fix- passes afterwards?You can find an example that's reasonably close to your case here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/chart2/qa/extras/chart2import.cxx#312

Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1Although a big change, I think it is safe. Only documents created outside of LibreOffice should currently be able to create document like this.  Plus, the ODF spec says it should be honoured anyway, if it is defined.The downside is that now the document will display properly, but if someone tries to edit those settings (and perhaps only GO to any format dialog, and then hit OK instead of cancel), the layout will reset to zero padding. Basically, we get read-only compatibility in 5.3, where before we had no compatibility at all.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1(Justin - don't argue with your superiors)  OK - take the response as an explanation for my thinking behind my actions. But yes, I don't trust git and certainly don't like the "document in git commit comments" theory.  Way too much noise in git blame/commits.  (Also an indication that I really have no clue how to properly use git log -p etc.)

Patch Set 1:Urk - using virtual inheritance for all of the OutputDevice ref and unref calls ... like this:class VCL_DLLPUBLIC OutputDevice : public virtual VclReferenceBaseI assume that this will then put all those nice previously in-lined, and optimize-able out mnRefCnt++ and -- pairs behind virtual function calls. But of course - we could look at the generated code to see if it in fact it is that awful ;-)What's the stripped binary size increase would be a good question.

Patch Set 3:I did notice the #N/A error in xls, but saw that as unavoidable as xls does not support LOGNORMDIST with 4 arguments.I could try to remove the 4th argument when not needed, but otherwise I see no solution; or should I convert to LOGNORM.DIST in these cases to preserve the formula?

Patch Set 3:> I did notice the #N/A error in xls, but saw that as unavoidable as > xls does not support LOGNORMDIST with 4 arguments. > I could try to remove the 4th argument when not needed, but > otherwise I see no solution; or should I convert to LOGNORM.DIST in > these cases to preserve the formula?Should be converted to LOGNORM.DIST, not removing arguments. Not sure at the moment how substituting with another function operator could be accomplished though, probably somewhere in sc/source/filter/excel/xeformula.cxx around XclExpFmlaCompImpl::ProcessFunction()

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Verified+1I don't know what happened. I updated my master build and applied this patch again and now it works. Sorry for fuzz.One thing remains, saving LOGNORMDIST(a,b,c,d) to BIFF .xls and reloading results in =NA(), probably because only 3 parameters are registered and we'd need to do the function rewrite there as well.

Patch Set 1:> > However I decided against it, since reading configuration on > every repaint brings some performance penalty >  > I see, just wondered if the performance penalty is really severe or > not. I didn't observe any slowdown myself, but that doesn't mean that other people wouldn't, who knows what they do with their office :) e.g. this blogpost explains why are frequent configuration readings a bad idea: https://mmohrhard.wordpress.com/2015/10/07/short-update-about-the-performance-testing/ > What we want then would be to derive utl::ConfigurationListener and > provide a suitable ConfigurationChanged( ::utl::ConfigurationBroadcaster*, > sal_uInt32 ), > as in Calc's ScModule (ScModule::ConfigurationChanged() in > sc/source/ui/app/scmod.cxx) > and Writer's SwModule (SwModule::ConfigurationChanged in > sw/source/uibase/app/apphdl.cxx), etc. > Right?Aye, that's exactly what I meant :)

Patch Set 3:Without looking too deeply, this smells like it might be breaking the implementation of the WebDAV content's "getPropertyValues" command for the sake of broken clients?  offapi/com/sun/star/ucb/Content.idl documents "getPropertyValues" as follows: "The execution will not be aborted, if there are properties requested, that are unknown to the content. The returned row object must contain a NULL value in the corresponding column instead."  (See css.sdbc.XRow.wasNull for how client code is supposed to check for such a "NULL value".)

Patch Set 3:You are probably right.Whith this I tried to overcome a probably wrong exception processing here:<http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/unotools/source/ucbhelper/ucbhelper.cxx#332>Where there is a css::uno::RuntimeException if the DataTime property is NULL, hence closing LO, badly.Probably rewriting the client code would be better?Rearranging it a bit should suffice.

Thanks.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1ODF has no restriction for x. In case x<0 the return value is 0. See http://docs.oasis-open.org/office/v1.2/os/OpenDocument-v1.2-os-part2.html#__RefHeading__1018684_715980110

Patch Set 2:Regina,Thank you for reminding. It could be argued that ODFF differs from many mathematical definitions, which require that x>=0.I have no idea how I missed the x<0 parts in ODFF - I read it 3 times.The bug report concerns GAMMA.DIST, an Excel function. I will change the code so that only GAMMA.DIST is affected.

Patch Set 2:This is wrong. Having column labels col2,col3 and row labels row2,row3 and a formula cell='col2' 'row2'that displays the intersection result, copy-pasting that to the next row now produces a #REF! result instead of the intersection='col2' 'row3'Which part is relative and which part is absolute indicates whether it is a column label or a row label, so this needs a different solution or additional work. Please fix or revert.

Patch Set 2:So, reverting it will reintroduce those two bugs this "fixes".This is one of these very common situations in Calc where, 1) the feature expectation is not very clear, 2) there is no test, 3) no code doc indicating how the code should behave, and 4) an attempt to fix stuff will get met with "this is wrong, please revert". ;-)Frustrating...

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1visually, LO round-trips this just fine, and has no problems with it. Only MS-Word indicates any issues, so no unit test is possible.The regression causing this issue covers an oddball situation already, so just avoiding the whole thing within a table seems like the best solution.I never could figure out what is ultimately causing the problem, because dealing with cells is very complicated. I'm pretty sure it was related to the anchor (position 26) being past the end of the string portions(0-23,24,25).  But even the delay of the first portion caused the +Fkp error, and nothing I tried stopped the cell "Enter Personal Websites  " from getting mangled except for completely avoiding postponement.

Patch Set 1:P.S. the 12.04 stuff is just a guess, but since no one else seems to be having compiling problems, I'm making that assumption.I have no idea WHY the exception occurs on 12.04 systems and not others (I have 16.04). Perhaps a knowledgeable person wants to question that (since it sounds like there is some attempt to swap in/out legacyparser? and this 12.04 stuff might affect that implementation)./autogen.sh  | grep -i xml  RESULTS IN        checking which libxml to use... external        checking for LIBXML... yes        checking for xmllint... /usr/bin/xmllintusr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libxml2.so.2.7.8

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Hi Justin; looks really great - but can we find where the exception comes from - and get a stack trace of that ? The way to do that is to put a break-point into where the 'try' is, and break in __cxa_throw and continue, and see what traces we get.I'm happy for this to go in in the meantime though of course, if it's breaking the build; that's bad; but could you file a bug and CC me on the trace ?Thanks !

Patch Set 1:not in both places?  Ideally eventually it can be fixed...I don't take reverting a unit test lightly, but this one has always been a complete thorn and I'm convinced that keeping in the code that allows it to currently pass is detrimental.  Thus the slightly modified unit test which looks terrible on released versions of 5.x, and mostly correct with all the changes in 5.3.  It certainly is WRONG before this patch hits, so it is a toss-up of one unit test verses another.With the regular page-break, it would be possible to switch to the follow style at that point (which in some cases would be too late, but better than nothing), but doing so has given me round-trip problems that I haven't been able to solve yet.  So one step at a time, and at least get this in before 5.3 releases.

Patch Set 1:As a demand from me, on behalf of the documentation team, every GSOC student has to document its achievements on features affecting the UI, so did Szymon. Otherwise we loose the developer/student and we are left alone with no explanation of the feature, and we have to guess what it is about to document it.If the feature is experimental, we can indicate that specific status. When it is fully accepted, we remove the warning and leave the help page as definitive.A help page on an experimental feature will harm nobody because, actually, it will give the opportunity to users to consciously try the feature and report experience.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2Yes, the code that makes a selection by indices looks unreachable to me. dbaccess seems to assume that "by bookmark" and "by indices" are two possibilities and to pass a selection along with a boolean flag to document which one it is. I'm not sure of the reasons for that, or if it is just historical cruft that has no reason to be anymore.I thought about just converting this (potentially unreachable) case to bookmarks, but getting the n_th row's bookmark is not immediately obvious... It requires moving the seek cursor (which can muck with expectations of other code about where the cursor is...). The safest would be to make a clone of the resultset and use that to get a bookmark,Anyway, this change is good to go as far as I'm concerned.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(4 comments)Looks good so far, but there is small problem with default creation:As soon as you override the CreateDefaultObject method, what happens is that SwFEShell::CreateDefaultShape is never called for all SIDs that use ConstRectangle. So:1. SwFEShell::CreateDefaultShape has code that previously handled line creation (OBJ_LINE case), and now it becomes unused.2. Some SIDs aren't properly handled in the new CreateDefaultObject, so e.g. if you create a textbox, it created outside the page, then "jumps" into its place.We have now 2 options:1. Implement support for all ConstRectangle based SIDs into CreateDefaultObject, and remove the unused code from SwFEShell::CreateDefaultShape.2. Not override CreateDefaultObject, and instead implement everything in SwFEShell::CreateDefaultShape.

Patch Set 1:> Not sure which installer you are using, but the windows installer > always installs the english UI. You can test this build which has 5 > default UIs. http://dev-builds.libreoffice.org/daily/master/Win-x86@62-merge-TDF/current/Huh? Isn't that "always" a bit too broad? :)When doing clean install, LO MSI installer selects UI languages (and dictionaries) based on locale and OS language. And believe me, if user locale is Russian under Russian OS, it doesn't select en-US UI by default. (It selects English dictionary, though.) Or you may see it here: https://youtu.be/iC2ZBt6wzs8However, if you bother to select some additional UIs, then on upgrade, it will detect already installed components and select every component installed, so you won't have to select it again.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2(1 comment)I advise against hardcoding specific services. Especially when they are only available in a small subset of languages.Letting special cases creep in like the one in flagged in the comment is even worse.Instead of hardcoding the ask site, make it a generic "find help online" or similar, that links to the domain specifically created for those kind of links: http://hub.libreoffice.org/something.That in turn can then redirect to language specific resources. (either redirect directly to askbot or show a overview page, depending on language. That then can be maintained/updated independently from LO (you cannot change the hardcoded URLs in a released version of LO after all)so again:* make it a generic page instead (not "Questions and Answers" but something like "Get help online" or something similar)* all URLs in LibreOffice itself should be http://hub.libreoffice.org/something ones.definite -2 because of the special handling of locales, without it it would still be a fat -1 from me

Patch Set 2:> perhaps the use of AsyncEventNotifier should be replaced by > dispatching to the default thread-pool? I think that is already > properly cleared on shutdown.oops, didn't notice your comment...what does "properly cleared" mean here? the problem why this crashed was that the SolarMutex was never released by the main thread until after DeInitVCL started killing VCL widgetry that the events in the AsyncEventNotifier thread had VclPtrs to, so the important aspect of the fix is that the Joining happens in a SolarMutexReleaser.this sounds quite scary but there is already a SolarMutexReleaser in DeInitVCL so i thought it shouldn't be any worse than before :)

Patch Set 5:it looks like we still owe you some answers to your questions :)the only way to build with python 2 is to use --enable-python=system and set PYTHON, PYTHON_CFLAGS and PYTHON_LIBS variables manually to the right values, i.e. PYTHON_CFLAGS=`pkg-config --cflags python` PYTHON_LIBS=`pkg-config --libs python` before running autogen.sh(this is deliberately inconvenient so that newbies don't do it by accident)the only easy way to run all python tests is "make check" but that will run all tests, the faster way is to run every PythonTest_foo that exists manually via "make PythonTest_foo".unfortunately it often happens that broken commits are pushed to master and that will break your jenkins build here too if your change is based on the broken master, probably that's what happened here in some cases.

Patch Set 1:IMHO I think there still is something wrong with FV:PartType value of -2 is evaluated in the function as FALSE, seehttps://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=100646#c0Please tell me if I'm right or wrong. In the first case I will amend my patch set to a better fix, in the second case I will abandon this submission and try to learn from your explanation.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1> IMHO I think there still is something wrong with FV: > PartType value of -2 is evaluated in the function as FALSE, see > https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=100646#c0 >  > Please tell me if I'm right or wrong. In the first case I will > amend my patch set to a better fix, in the second case I will > abandon this submission and try to learn from your explanation.Bah, you're right, the "boolean" is evaluated completely strange in ScGetZw() where we have if(fF > 0.0){}else{} so actually all values <=0 act as FALSE. What a nonsense..So that should be changed from double fF to bool bF and all functions calling ScGetZw() should obtain the argument value using GetBool() instead of GetDouble().We probably will have to mention that change in the release notes, because it may alter calculation results, even if from wrong to right ...

Patch Set 1:Hmm... I'm not convinced that misusing a toolbox controller as a way to place a control inside a .ui file is a good approach in general. It might be fine for simple controls like comboboxes, because those can be placed on a "classic" toolbar too, but using it for a whole panel seems like overkill. Why not register SlideTransitionPane as a proper glade control, and use it directly?About the late init problem: You can try some kind of event notification. If none of the existing notifications proves to be useful - you can use the dispatch status updates mechanism. (And of course making the whole notebookbar init much later is an option too, but I have no idea how hard it would be.)

Patch Set 5:(4 comments)To make it clear: You don't really need to create a toolbox control to receive status updates. All you need is to implement XStatusListener interface and register yourself in the dispatcher. There is even a helper class svt::FrameStatusListener which you can derive from. But that's your choice, of course...

Patch Set 8:> How can I get value from LeftRightParaMargin command using normal > sfx2 mechanism? I've tried to change its return type: > -SfxVoidItem LeftRightParaMargin SID_ATTR_PARA_LRSPACE > +SvxLRSpaceItem LeftRightParaMargin SID_ATTR_PARA_LRSPACE > (SvxLRSpaceItem LRSpace SID_ATTR_PARA_LRSPACE)This is wrong. LeftRightParaMargin is a method slot, so what you need instead is to add an explicit SlotType = SvxLRSpaceItem.

Patch Set 3:@Maxim Monastirsky: Thank you very much for pointers! I've just updated repo and started the build. Tomorrow I will check if it works :)

Patch Set 3:> I left the normal sfx2 mechanism because using the StateChanged > method I had got different values than the field in the sidebar.  > Do you know why values from ::sfx2::sidebar::ControllerItem are > different? Different units? I looked into its code, it seems to > pass received values directly to the notify receiver, so I don't > understand.I confirm that at least for .uno:ULSpacing values are different. And the cause is this: Take a look at SvxULSpaceItem::QueryValue and SvxULSpaceItem::PutValue. Both have nMemberId argument. If it's 0, the value is read/write without conversion, but if it's CONVERT_TWIPS then the value is converted from/to 1/100th mm.Now, when the original SfxPoolItem is converted to the UNO status thing, that conversion is made (as documented in offapi/com/sun/star/frame/status/UpperLowerMarginScale.idl ...) - see SfxDispatcher::QueryState and SfxDispatchController_Impl::StateChanged. But when this is used in SfxToolBoxControl::statusChanged to re-construct the SfxPoolItem, there is simply hardcoded 0 passed to SfxPoolItem::PutValue. Of course this doesn't affect ControllerItem, because it gets the original SfxPoolItem from sfx2.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1Love it - thanks for the swamp draining Markus ! =) I guess my lingering concern is what happens when we have SEH enabled code that catches a SEGV vs. normal code - does that mean we get various exceptions thrown out of eg. OGL drivers that are compiled with this option (?) etc. anyhow - moving closer to the Linux case sounds like a good idea to me for window stability =)Thanks.

Patch Set 2:> Love it - thanks for the swamp draining Markus ! =) I guess my > lingering concern is what happens when we have SEH enabled code > that catches a SEGV vs. normal code - does that mean we get various > exceptions thrown out of eg. OGL drivers that are compiled with > this option (?) etc. anyhow - moving closer to the Linux case > sounds like a good idea to me for window stability =) >  > Thanks.So EHs only affects whether we catch the SEH or not. It does not affect how other code handles it. Of course if we get a lot of SEH excepions from outside of our control that are currently caught in one of the catch all handlers we are going to crash a lot.EHs has basically two effects on the code. catch(...) will not catch SEH exceptions and there is no stack nwinding and destructor calls going to be for SEH exceptions.I think both are fine in our code. The case that some external part is handling SEH with EHa should not concern us as if we get a SEH from that cod ewe will just crash and if that code handles it we are not going to see it anyway.

Patch Set 1:it looks safe to me:1. OWeakObject::release does atomic_decrement(m_refCount)2. ~OWeakObject calls disposeWeakConnectionPoint, then OWeakConnectionPoint::dispose, then OWeakRefListener::dispose3. OWeakRefListener::dispose locks the mutex4. OWeakRefListener::dispose clears m_pObject5. OWeakRefListener::dispose locks the mutex6. only after all listeners are disposed, m_refCount is *freed*so any access between 1. and 3. of OWeakConnectionPoint::m_pObject will observe m_pObject->m_refCount == 0 and do nothing,any access between 3. and 6. will observe m_pObject == nullptr and do nothing

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1C:/cygwin/home/tdf/lode/jenkins/workspace/lo_gerrit_master/Gerrit/Gerrit/Platform/Windows/vcl/win/gdi/salgdi.cxx(625) : error C2259: 'WinSalGraphicsImpl' : cannot instantiate abstract classdue to following members:'void SalGraphicsImpl::SetXORMode(bool,bool)' : is abstractc:cygwinhometdflodejenkinsworkspacelo_gerrit_mastergerritgerritplatformwindowsvclincsalgdiimpl.hxx(80) : see declaration of 'SalGraphicsImpl::SetXORMode'you can't remove the parameter only in the Windows-specific derived class, if you want to remove it you have to remove it in SalGraphicsImpl and every class derived from that (there is at least one per platform).the bug says that the Mac OS X backend may or may not actually use the parameter, so the first thing to be done here is to clarify the situation on Mac OS X - if it turns out that the 2nd parameter is still in use there, it cannot be removed.

Patch Set 1:> What is the actual purpose of this?The formula bar in LOK case is not tiled rendered, so we cannot interact with theformula bar directly. In this case, we need a way so that client applicationscan simulate a formula bar.> Why not update dependent formula cells, conditional formatting and so on?We do not want to update dependent formula cells with each keystroke when theuser is still writing his/her input into the formula bar because these areintermediate values. It could be an incomplete formula or an invalid value whichwould result in throwing error for all dependent cells. We only want to updatethese dependent cells in some particular condition, say pressing enter, informula bar. Hence the distinction in this UNO command now, so that when theuser is just typing, we don't commit the contents to the cell.I tried looking for other ways to accomplish this, but this approach made mostsense to me. Surely, if you have any suggestions, please let me know :-)> What should happen if one enters a numeric value / date / formula?The cell should go in edit mode with each keystroke in formula bar updating itscontents but not commit till we press enter(by not specifying DontCommit param).

Patch Set 1:When you click on something else, the focus is lost, the SvxFillTypeBox gets a "PreNotify" of LOSEFOCUS and calls "SelectEntryPos" of nCurPos.nCurPos is set on a MouseButton down/GetFocus so its the value before it was changed.The intention seems to be to be able to restore the old pos if you hit esc. nCurPos will not be used if bSelect is true, calling "Selected" on the SvxFillTypeBox sets that.So it looks like missing "Selected" calls on it, there are "Selected" calls in the svx/source/sidebar/area/AreaPropertyPanelBase.cxx equivalent

Patch Set 1:(4 comments)* For now, this class is used in exactly one place.  Personally, I wouldn't bother adding it to comphelper for now, but if you think it'll be used in further places, that's probably OK.  However, the feature of passing in two different interaction handlers is unused, so better remove it.  (YAGNI, and our aggressive approach at removing unused code---which we need to keep the huge code base maintainable---would remove it again, anyway.)* The license headers of the new files can be the first variant from TEMPLATE.SOURCECODE.HEADER, I think, as there's no existing code ending up in the new files.

Patch Set 6:I don't think this is a good change.  The default css.task.InteractionHandler service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should be controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail the client's request with an exception.

Patch Set 6:> I don't think this is a good change.  The default css.task.InteractionHandler > service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should be > controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall > happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail the > client's request with an exception.it will still fail if it's the case, the hanlder it's only used in case of Web/DAV authentication needed, not in exception bypass.That is, if an exception is thrown, it will be reported back, cancelCommandExecution will still work using the original CommandEnv, the one set by the client.

Patch Set 6:> > I don't think this is a good change.  The default > css.task.InteractionHandler > > service that is created here presents UI to the user.  It should > be > > controllable by the UCP's client what kind of interaction shall > > happen; if no interaction handler is given, the UCP shall fail > the > > client's request with an exception. >  > it will still fail if it's the case, the hanlder it's only used in > case of Web/DAV authentication needed, not in exception bypass. >  > That is, if an exception is thrown, it will be reported back, > cancelCommandExecution will still work using the original > CommandEnv, the one set by the client.I think you misunderstood me.  If the client code (on purpose) passes in no interaction handler for some command to the UCP, and the UCP gets into a situation where it would want to consult a passed-in interaction handler, then the UCP must abort the command by throwing an exception back to the client, instead of creating its own interaction handler out of thin air.

Patch Set 6:> But that doesn't answer my question:  What is the problem this > change wants to solve?I'll try to give an explanation, by describing what happens.Please have a look at this gerrit already pushed (originally it was in the same series with this one):https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/gitweb?p=core.git;a=commitdiff;h=e1ae21889a214ea3b6f79018d3c710d75fc8fba6probably I should have kept both merged in a single gerrit patch set.Anyway, Kendy description I removed explained what this patch fixes.This is the callback Kenky is referring to in his comment (NeonSession_CertificationNotify):http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#354in this callback, here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#455the interaction handler is needed because it's the only way the user is notified that something went wrong during web connection because of SSL certificate problem.If a CommandEnv is available, the certificate is further checked, the real check is performed here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#248In handleCertificateValidationRequest_  the user is asked if the certificate can be trusted anyway, should some of the checks carried out there fails.Upon returning of a successfull interaction '0' is returned to neon, which go on processing the request.In the use case addressed with the patch (e.g. accessing a mozilla web site) the user interaction is not called, because the test Kendy reports as failing("In the case of services.addons.mozilla.com, the certificate is for versioncheck.addons.mozilla.com, but it also has...") is addressed inside handleCertificateValidationRequest_starting here:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#276down to this last check:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/uui/source/iahndl-ssl.cxx#300That can't be done if CommandEnv is missing.If this patch is not present, NeonSession_CertificationNotify always returns '1', returning '1' to neon, neon will stop the processing notifiying the caller 'Server certificate verification failed: issuer is not trusted',which in due time it's converted to a 'ucb::InteractiveNetworkReadException'.The root call to access file is this:http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/cui/source/options/personalization.cxx#582As you can see the catch clause doesn't deal with the exception mentioned above, and besides, nothing can be done by the UCB client if SSL certificates aresuspicious or wrong or in need of a deeper check.The missing CommandEnv is common in UCB client use of Web/WebDAV connection, what do we do when we end up with the same problem, about certificates?Or in another possibility, not yet addressed, if the remote web server challenges to obtain credentials and no interaction handler is available to serve them?

Patch Set 6:> in this callback, here: > http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/ucb/source/ucp/webdav-neon/NeonSession.cxx#455 > the interaction handler is needed because it's the only way the > user is notified that something went wrong during web connection > because of SSL certificate problem.[...] > The root call to access file is this: > http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/cui/source/options/personalization.cxx#582Then that latter place needs to be fixed to actually pass in a suitable interaction handler (by not using the inappropriate XSimpleFileAccess wrapper).

Patch Set 6:> > XSimpleFileAccess wrapper does have a method to set the > interaction > > handler >  > Ah, right, css.ucb.XSimpleFileAccess.setInteractionHandler.  The > code in cui/source/options/personalization.cxx can supposedly only > be triggered by GUI interaction, so it should be OK to call >  > xFileAccess->setInteractionHandler( > css::task::InteractionHandler::create(xContext)); >  > there to set the default (GUI) interaction handler.this is what I checked first.Works, but in case of errors (Internet connection, temporary DNS problem or anything such) there is a verbose error indication coming out of ucbhelper::cancelCommandExecution.Looking at the code in cui/source/options/personalization.cxx the original developer intended disabling it.I was thinking more on the line to implement something similar tocomphelper::StillReadWriteInteraction in order to interact with the user only when certificate problems are involved and have the other exception reported back, specifically thought to be used when a simple file access is needed.May came in handy on other occasions (some of them I already spotted for WebDAV).What do you think. ?

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)step 1 was to find all unused using declarationsby searching all and check if the symbol reappears in the source file. Even if it's in dead code or comments, but exclude appearances in #include statements.this was done by script, header were excluded the top removes symbols were:72	xinterface60	exception *36	xmultiservicefactory35	mutexguard35	runtimeexception *20	xpropertyset14	xpropertysetinfo13	illegalargumentexception *13	xparameters13	xpreparedstatement12	xcloseable11	wrappedtargetexception11	xcomponent11	xmodel10	nosuchelementexception *10	theme10	xresultset*) unclear to me where they usually come from#!/bin/bashIFS=$'\n'str_search="^\s*using\s+[\w:]+::\w+;"for str_using in $( git grep -nP "$str_search" ); do        filename=$(echo $str_using | sed -r 's/^(.*\.\w+):.*;.*/\1/')        symbol=$(echo "$str_using" | perl -pe "s|^.*using\s+(?:(?:::)?\w+)*::(\w+);.*|\1|")        line=$(echo "$str_using" | perl -pe "s|^.*:([0-9]+):.*;|\1|")        lines=$(git grep -P "([^\w"\""/]|^)$symbol([^\w]|$)" $filename| wc -l)        usages=$(($lines - 1))        echo 'in file '$filename': symbol: '$symbol' usages: '$usages        if [ $lines -eq 1 ]        then                echo 'in file '$filename':#'$line' declaration of '$symbol' is unused'                sed -i -r "/[^[:alnum:]_]$symbol;/d" "$filename"        fidonenext step will be to check if removed declarations had a included header with the same name in the file and try to remove them.e.g. using ::com::sun::star::lang::XServiceInfo; got removed so remove#include <com/sun/star/lang/XServiceInfo.hpp> too.

Patch Set 5:> In this case, nDstLocation was > always 0, so nDstLocation<<1 (multiply by 2, right?) didn't do > anything this time, but in other situations it might be critical.I'm not sure what had in mind that the person who wrote this code to do the nDstLocation*2, I think that it tries to compensate later for fTemp but as this was always 0, that didn't work correctly.In any case with the new code this is not necessary anymore, it was only used when mirroring and the new code has the same behavior as the original when there is no mirroring and additionally, treats also mirroring correctly >  > Also, if nOutDimention == 1, you will have a divide by zero > exception.Correct, a have added a condition to check for this and make fReverseScale equal to 0 in this situation. Thanks :)Apologizes for the delay in answering.

Patch Set 2:Not providing a code review - don't feel qualified b/c I don't understand all of the logic.The fix worked for the test document on Mint 12.04.  (16.04 already worked before the fix.)  However, I'm afraid that too much may have been changed in the code - so that it works for this instance, but doesn't work in other situations.  In this case, nDstLocation was always 0, so nDstLocation<<1 (multiply by 2, right?) didn't do anything this time, but in other situations it might be critical. Also, if nOutDimention == 1, you will have a divide by zero exception.So perhaps your logic is fine (I don't know), but my gut feeling is that it fits the test case only and will break other situations.

Patch Set 3:> Let me explain in more detail... >  > It is common in code to use a clever trick to get more informative > text into the message from a failed assert(). For instance, one > could have (this a generic example, not from LibreOffice): >  > assert(nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo widget"); >  > with the intent being that in case nFoo is <= 0, instead of the > message: >  > Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 >  > one would get this message, with a longer explanation: >  > Assertion failed: nFoo > 0 && "We should have at least one foo > widget" >  > In the code lines here, the string literal contains what is > essentially identical to the expression on the left side of the && > operator, so it does not give any additional information.ohh, now i understand. Actually i never used assert in any of my programming projects. I'm a 1-2 yr amatuer C++ programmer. Whatever the result may be, open source coding is always a great learning experience. Thanks for such a great explanation. I would update all of my patches tommorow morning.

Patch Set 5:> Just curious, what's the benefit of genLang, compared to the > current l10ntools, after the kill-sdf branch was merged? >  > See http://libreoffice.hu/2012/11/27/featurekillsdf-branch-merged/ > for the background.the kill sdf was a very good thing, but it did not change the tools or the method. The "save" method in the old tools was rewritten to save .pot files.genLang "reinvents" the tools in a C++ fashion, making it more maintainable. You can however argue, that since the old tools work, why change it. The best reason for that is to move away from the central "make translations" that runs find over the source tree, and into adding the files to the local makefiles (e.g. define ui files like you define cxx files).

Patch Set 3:> Unfortunately, this upgrade hasn't fixed compilation breakage on > MSVC 14.0, 32bit: [1]. >  > * [1] http://paste.openstack.org/show/487962Looking into the breakage now:  winnt.h(3660): note: see declaration of '_CONTEXT'  winnt.h(7214): error C2011: '_CONTEXT': 'struct' type redefinitionand looking at those areas in the winnt.h file, it appears, that the _CONTEXT definition on the line 3660 is guarded with:  // begin_ntoshvp  #ifdef _AMD64_  [...]  #endif // _AMD64_whereas the _CONTEXT definition on line 7214 is guarded with  // begin_ntoshvp  #ifdef _X86_  [...]  #endif // _X86_Somehow nss seems to have both defines on MSVC 14.0 32bit (it works as expected on 64bit).

Patch Set 13:(5 comments)> I didn't notice ScTabViewShell::GetState() warning. But i don't > know how can i handle it.It has a switch where you can handle the commands similar to the Execute method, but this time for the command state. A state of a command is how the UI element (toolbar button, menu item etc.) that bound to this command presented to the user. It can be enabled/disabled, checked/unchecked, its text can dynamically change etc.wrt our case, I see that .uno:FreezePanes is enabled always, even in a read-only doc, and so should be the new commands, so this isn't an issue. What GetState currently does for .uno:FreezePanes is that it sets checked/unchecked state. But I wonder whether we want something similar for the new commands (i.e. detect if the first row/column is frozen and set checked state accordingly), or maybe such indication isn't that useful, and we can just drop the GetState part from tabvwsh.sdi as well.Eike: What do you think on this?

Patch Set 7:Please, no need to describe the various phases of the gerrit review process in the commit message. That is just confusing when somebody is reading the commit message after some time. Just describe what the change does, as a whole, at the current (last) stage. Also, use present tense, as in "Add new Freeze...". Sorry for nit-picking, but good commit messages are important.

Patch Set 1:Isn't client code supposed to (ideally, once the coding conventions has stabilised) use the *_HAS macros to find out if the LibreOffice instance being used provides an API? Ideally a client should not need to know what version of LibreOffice it is running against, so these notations are perhaps thus of questionable use and misleading. Just a thought, feel free to ignore.

Patch Set 1:> Isn't client code supposed to (ideally, once the coding conventions > has stabilised) use the *_HAS macros to find out if the LibreOffice > instance being used provides an API? Ideally a client should not > need to know what version of LibreOffice it is running against, so > these notations are perhaps thus of questionable use and > misleading. Just a thought, feel free to ignore.I've added the since annotation in the C code because the system i use with the binding does not support ifdefery  > Isn't client code supposed to (ideally, once the coding conventions > has stabilised) use the *_HAS macros to find out if the LibreOffice > instance being used provides an API? Ideally a client should not > need to know what version of LibreOffice it is running against, so > these notations are perhaps thus of questionable use and > misleading. Just a thought, feel free to ignore.I've added the annotation to the C header because i can't use ifdefery in the python bindings. So knowing when stuff was added helps me track a specific libreoffice version as requirement. This patch is done for keeping it in sync with the C one as Miklos told me this is the one that gets the documentation.

Patch Set 2:Oh yes. Sry. Just woke up.Had to fix it as it broke the build and forgot to leave a message.For the solution how to push such a patch to gerrit. You need to update to a git checkout that ncludes the pushed patch already. One solution to avoid long recompile times is to have a separate push tree + charry-picking the commit from current master. Then only add the new commit to the push tree (which already contains the pushed commit) and push to gerrit for review.Gerrit complained that you tried to push a patch that has been merged already to gerrit review. This happens because the Change-Id of the patch was the same as the merged one.

It used to have its own bootstrapping mechanism, which wasn't working with new LO anymore, so I killed it in favour of javaunohelper bootstrap. It however used to have the feature of passing custom options to bootstrapped soffice, which core LO didn't have until this commit.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I seem to be missing the point of removing the non-relative-to-indent tab stop handling within the ruler.Writer (unfortunately) was initially designed in a way that tab stops are calculated from the left paragraph indent.To be compatible to doc/docx a non-relative usage of tab stops has been added which is (again unfortunately) only used for doc/docx import. If you remove that code the ruler will show wrong tab stops in docx/doc import.

Patch Set 1:> I seem to be missing the point of removing the non-relative-to-indent > tab stop handling within the ruler.Please take a look at tdf#95846, which itself is based on tdf#76005 (linked there as See Also...). I noted the relevant OOo issue there, too. > Writer (unfortunately) was initially designed in a way that tab > stops are calculated from the left paragraph indent. > To be compatible to doc/docx a non-relative usage of tab stops has > been added which is (again unfortunately) only used for doc/docx > import.I see; that is what I explain in my first comment here... > If you remove that code the ruler will show wrong tab stops in > docx/doc import.The whole point is that _having_ this code in ruler _does_ make it show wrong tab stops in doc/docx import. You may notice in the tdf issue, that I discuss the bug manifestation vector to be exactly that: importing docx. Actually, you confirm that the flag is used on import only, and then the tabs are stored in memory in usual LO way (relative to left paragraph indent). From there, they are fed into the ruler code (being usual relative-to-indent), so why does it need to treat them differently in this case?

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1The naming is ~irrelevant to me; but it should be consistent between 5-1 to master and then locked down IMHO.JanI - we want to see how many threads there are that can run concurrently to start implementing code that best exploits the parallelism out there. The exact processor geometry etc. is too much potentially identifying information IMHO.As such the naming is pretty ~irrelevant IMHO; best not to quibble.

Patch Set 1: -Code-Review> As such the naming is pretty ~irrelevant IMHO; best not to quibble.Happen to disagree. "CPU threads" is for me very different from "threads", but of course might be because I am too deep into how the CPU works.Will not block this, but neither promote it.

Patch Set 1:This seems a ridiculous discussion to me ;-) doer decides is a vital meritocratic principle =) quibbling adds little value it seems to me.Beyond that - there is nothing simple about APU hardware; we have both GPU and CPU compute resources with things akin to threads in them. Cores is also an horribly misleading term in a SMT world. There are even pending law-suits around "what is a core" - how many resources can be shared etc. There is no "obvious" answer to this question.What we are returning is: the result of std::thread::hardware_concurrency() - we can provide a hyper-descriptive label for this: but then we'll be sending a truck-load of these across the net for years, and there is only so much space in Help->About =)What is in the patch has the merit of brevity; if someone wants to change it to CPU Threads Hardware Concurency - to follow STL or whatever, they are welcome to - preferably in a separate, follow-up patch - that also line-wraps this for Help->About.

Patch Set 2:(1 comment)Follow up of the draft already proposed.This will work if UNX symbol defined, in Linux should be defined because it works, though I didn't find where UNX symbol is defined.On Windows the connect timeout can't work, simply because it's not managed in neon, e.g. need to add code to neon to manage it.In Windows it will be the operating system timeout then (in my Windows 7 is 20 sec each connect try).On Mac I can't check: I don't have access to a system.The patch set second in the series, actually halves the time needed to detect the 'no connect' situation, so it will work on Windows too.Probably this will need some check on the client applications (framework, sw, sd... etc.) if there is no side effect for possible nasty side effect.Didn't see any, but I don't know the code (of framework, sw, sc, etc...).Re. cpp unit test: in this specific case the test should be enabled only when UNX is defined.Ucb lacks completely cpp unit test case, there is something in java only.Adding some of them, to check WebDAV stuff not tied to external server (e.g. URL manipulation methods) it's something I've been thinking about for some time.I'll ask on mail list for help, it'll be matter for another patch.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Works, but.. ;) something strange is going on: in A1 type =sum( select column B press Enter in A2 type =sum(and as soon as the opening ( parenthesis is typed, the string ,B1048576 is inserted before, so the resulting string is =sum,B1048576(This is repeatable if Escape is pressed instead of confirming the resulting string. When pressing a cursor key after (, a range selection starts at the last selected position, in this example with Cursor-Right that results in =sum,B1048576(B1048576:C1048576The behavior does not occur if the application window is switched and back before entering =sum(Apparently the last position is remembered and not cleared from the view and reused in a bad context.

Patch Set 4:> Works, but.. ;) something strange is going on: >  > in A1 type =sum( > select column B > press Enter > in A2 type =sum( >  > and as soon as the opening ( parenthesis is typed, the string > ,B1048576 is inserted before, so the resulting string is >  > =sum,B1048576(Noticed that this happens when user types "=sum" and then presses one of the keys (alt, ctrl, shift). This only happens when user did not move/touch the mouse after last mouse-button-up event. Also found that void ScHeaderControl::MouseMove is getting called when the above mentioned keys (alt, ctrl, shift) is pressed even though there is no actual mouse movement !To solve this I had to work around by adding a flag bDoneInitRef.

Patch Set 4:Michael, many thanks for the review. I have fixed the name, also improved the patch to limit GetObject only at repeated image loading/overloading, and pushed to the master. (The  repeated image loading could be a result of the repaint triggered by the second call of GetObject - after the successful asynchronous loading of an image.)
Patch Set 5:(2 comments)Still confused here ?

Patch Set 6:> FnHashSet ? - what is the function ? surely a better, more descriptive type name is possibleI have renamed as AsyncLoads in the patch set 6.> Also - I suggested a much clearer name for this hash; but ... this is not it =)I had already changed the member variable name, but you checked an older patch set (patch set 3 instead of the last 5 at that time). > Why have this variable rather than using an empty-hash (and hence no lookup match) ?I have already removed that code in the patch set 6.> Why are we erasing here ? this seems inexplicable to me; I commented on it before; you seem to have responded to the comment - but this is not clear.> If the load of this filename is in-progress - then we prematurely remove it from being in-progress here, before it is loaded (right?) - why ?We want to skip only one LoadFile_Impl() call to avoid immediate paint and recursive image loadings. This skipped LoadFile_Impl() call is the last for the object, when the image loading is finished (see backtrace "Second LoadFile_Impl() call of an asynchronous image loading" in the Bug 95614).Or this call can be the first LoadFile_Impl() call of an other SvFileObject loading the same picture, so we won't start that image loading immediately.This stops freezing with linked images and recent scheduler.Many thanks for the review.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Seems reasonable enough I guess - I would name the member variable something sensible; m_aAsyncLoadsInProgress.I'm also really unclear why we erase the item from the hash if it is already there - when requesting the image [ that seems ... odd ] Surely we want to erase that when the async loading has completed (whether it succeeded or failed) - rather than when the 2nd image request is made (what about a 3rd request ?).Anyhow - conceptually loading the same graphic twice does indeed look bogus & good to stop; though whether this is truly the root cause of the freeze is unclear to me =)Thanks.

Patch Set 4:> > RGB happens to be defined by wingdi.h and leaks from multiple > > places. This was the easiest/simplest fix; to undef it where it > > conflicts. For other cases it was enough to undef them in > postwin.h > > and make sure it's called after including windows headers. >  > But wouldn't it be better to handle undef'ing RGB in postwin.h, and > make sure any include of wingdi.h is wrapped in prewin/postwin.h? I tried that. And can give it another try. But it would require a much bigger change, obviously. The main problem is that wingdi.h is actually included from other windows headers too. So we can't fully control when it's included. But can give it another shot and narrow it down further. In fact, I spent hours trying to find what file includes the conflicting values to create this patch. > The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx > to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that > officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants > to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into > a problem.Well, that would be be a problem _only_ if wingdi.h was already included _before_ Office/Common.h, and in that case the build would fail because the macro would conflict with the declaration of RGB (my patch avoids this situation).However, if wingdi.h was _not_ included at the point of #undef RGB, then nothing bad would happen if it is included afterwards. Unless I missed something, I don't see how there would still be a problem, as wingdi.h will define RGB without issue.I should add that I hated this particular line of my patch. I share your view that it's best avoided altogether. But I couldn't find a better solution. Will try again though.

Patch Set 4:> > The current fix allows workdir/CustomTarget/officecfg/registry/officecfg/Office/Common.hxx > > to be included, but if a source file happens to first include that > > officecfg/Office/Common.hxx, then include wingdi.h, and later wants > > to acutally use the struct RGB from Common.hxx, it still runs into > > a problem. >  > Well, that would be be a problem _only_ if wingdi.h was already > included _before_ Office/Common.h, and in that case the build would > fail because the macro would conflict with the declaration of RGB > (my patch avoids this situation). >  > However, if wingdi.h was _not_ included at the point of #undef RGB, > then nothing bad would happen if it is included afterwards. Unless > I missed something, I don't see how there would still be a problem, > as wingdi.h will define RGB without issue.But assume wingdi.h does  #define RGB foo(or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then has code  officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get();that would be pre-processed to  officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get();and fail to compile.

Patch Set 4:>  > But assume wingdi.h does >  > #define RGB foo >  > (or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file > including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then > has code >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get(); >  > that would be pre-processed to >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get(); >  > and fail to compile.Of course. But my change will neither help nor harm that case :)(I only fixed the reverse, which is that wingdi.h is included before Common.hxx.)And I believe that case doesn't exist now (if they existed, I fixed them).Containing windows headers in postwin.h will help (which I fully support). But even then, once a header that includes wingdi.h (directly or indirectly) is included in the pch, then we still face the same issue. So it's really tricky.Since I was working on pch files, it was this latter case that really made things complicated. The way to avoid that is to never include an uncontained header that leaks in the pch, which is what we do. So the only case that breaks the build is when RGB is defined before Office/Common.hxx, which I patched.Actually, I think what we should do is add #undef RGB to postwin.h (even when currently it's not needed). I think that's the right thing to do and guarantee that wingdi.h is as contained as possible at all times.

Patch Set 4:> But assume wingdi.h does >  > #define RGB foo >  > (or whatever exactly it defines RGB to), and the .cxx file > including first officecfg/Office/Common.hxx and then wingdi.h then > has code >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::RGB::Red::get(); >  > that would be pre-processed to >  > officecfg::Office::Common::Image::Color::foo::Red::get(); >  > and fail to compile.I've addressed this issue in a separate patch (#20039) pending review.

Patch Set 4:I wish we had aw080 already, all SdrObjects fully transformable, mirroring preserved...The current Rectangle unfortunately allows such bad/inconsistent states (left() > right()), thats why justify is needed (and why B2DRange is better, this can not happen). The Rectangle is *not* the place to keep such information. It's place is at the model (the SdrObject). See ::TRGetBaseGeometry implementations where the mirroring is coming from - e.g in SdrObjCustomShape it *is* a model member (X and Y).Currently - except for the SdrObjCustomShape and SdrGrafObj - the mirrored states are not preserved - the mirroring is geometrically *executed* on the existing geometry, that's it (aw080 changes this).You can see this sad truth e.g. at the graphic object - insert one in Draw/Impress and add text. Hor mirror does not change the text at all, vertical mirror uses a 180 deg rotation, *not* a true vert mirroring.This only does not come to more attention due to the fact that nearly all shapes are CustomShapes nowadays...Do not forget: mirror in X and Y equals a 180 deg rotation (can be seen/proved looking at the corrresponding homogen matrix)

Patch Set 4:(1 comment)You do what is possible with the current model - execute flips on the existing geometry. Just be aware that a call to TRGetBaseGeometry will not return these changes. Flip handling needs to be moved before shear.

Patch Set 1:To elaborate on how to amend a patch: The trick here is preserving the same Change-Id of the commit message, so that Gerrit recognizes it should be on the same thread. Locally, you do a new commit, then you do `git rebase -i HEAD~2' to squash that with the previous commit. Then you push and Gerrit will detect your updated squashed commit as a new version (or ÔÇ£patch setÔÇØ) without creating a new thread. Hope this helps!

Patch Set 1:> To elaborate on how to amend a patch: The trick here is preserving > the same Change-Id of the commit message, so that Gerrit recognizes > it should be on the same thread. Locally, you do a new commit, then > you do `git rebase -i HEAD~2' to squash that with the previous > commit.Git commit --amend is a much easier way to do that.iow checkout your gerrit patchdo the modificationscommit them using --amendgit push origin HEAD:refs/for/master Then you push and Gerrit will detect your updated squashed > commit as a new version (or ÔÇ£patch setÔÇØ) without creating a new > thread. Hope this helps!

Patch Set 3:> Now it the real VS2015 released, we should make sure that our > VS2015 stuff works for somebody who has only the release version > installed, and no betas, RCs etc.Sure. But how should I be able to verify this change supports final MSVC 14.0 before it was released? >  > Also, I am not sure why you remove the 10.0A SDK from the > WINDOWS_SDK_ACCEPTABLE_VERSIONS. Surely the default should be that > the SDK included with the compiler is sufficient and default?May be I got it wrong, but I haven't found SDK on the net that has this name. But yes, there is SDK 10.0, but note, that this SDK is not included with the compiler. This is confusing. Only universal CRT is included under C:\Program Files (x86)\Windows Kits\10 directory. So you cannot build LO, when only MSVC 14.0 compiler is installed, you still need SDK 8.1 or 10.0 (this is explained in the commit message). I tested this change against SDK 8.1.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1OMG, just checking on MSVC 12.0 (aka VS 2013) and seeing that all VS projects filea are not compatible any more with MSVC < 1900. Universal runtime was introduced only in MSVC 14.0 and it is hard coded in project files, so no wonder the compilation is failing with:  LINK : fatal error LNK1104: Datei "ucrtd.lib" kann nicht geÔûÆffnet werden.   [C:\Users\david\projects\libo\workdir\UnpackedTarball\python3\PCBuild\pylauncher.vcxproj]Now what?  Python 3.5 cannot be compiler with VS 2013 out of the box (I havn't looked how hard would be to fix that). Python 3.3 cannot be compiled with VS 2015. I wonder if we can conditionally switch between Python 3.3 and 3.5 during configuration process? But makefile changes are very intrusive (see this change), so it would be a lot of fun to support different compiler versions. So probably the only option is disruptive change: discontinue VS 2013 in favor of VS 2015.

Patch Set 3:Now I am confused, are these really equivalent?

Patch Set 3:Replying to myself: Yeah, they are.USING_X11 is TRUE when we are building for a platform that uses X11, and we haven't used the --without-x option. with_x is "no" when we have used the switch --without-x (which used to be called --enable-headless), and that de facto has been developed only for platforms where X11 *could* be used. So USING_X11!=TRUE turns out to be equivalent to with_x==no. Unless I miss something;)In theory one could also imagine building a LibreOffice for Windows or OS X that would not use any display-oriented APIs, but that would be fairly pointless, as that functionality is always present in the OS anyway. It isn't like Linux, where some people think it is useful to have installations without any X11 stuff.

Patch Set 2:(1 comment)I wonder whether we really want those dispose calls all over the place? I'm assuming that the SvxFontNameBox_Impl case is unique, in sense that it owns the FontList and the FontList holds references to SvxFontNameBox_Impl, so none of them can be destructed. Is it the case in other places too? In case the FontInfo dtor *is* called, why call also the dispose method?See also one inline comment.

Patch Set 6:> Screencast - https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B6qJrVIa0SAlRDF6RjhWWFo0dTA/view?usp=sharingThanks. This is perfect. Will investigate further.

Patch Set 6:I checked MSO and i was mistaken with my assumptions, all is fine except that the left and right margins should be left as is. The intent of the feature is to eliminate white space between (above and below) pages, so there is less scrolling up and down through the document, so there isnt a to need hide left and right margins, as that alters how the page would be displayed, as more content jumps to previous pages. It seems that removing the header and footer also causes content to jump to the previous page, as the page isnt being cropped but instead the content is allowed to flow within the full size of the page space.In case i didnt mention it before, i am part of the design and UX teams. :D

Patch Set 6:> so there isnt a to need hide left and right margins,Should we hide left/right margins in book-view and multipage-view ?Let me update the patch and let you play with left/right margins hidden only in book- and multipage-view, and see what you think. > It seems that removing the header and > footer also causes content to jump to the previous page, as the > page isnt being cropped but instead the content is allowed to flow > within the full size of the page space.Yes. I mentioned this somewhere as a limitation. The reason for this is that the page size is the same, but the margins are removed/reduced. So the text is allowed to fill in more surface area. This could be solved by changing the page dimensions in hide-whitespace mode. I didn't try to do that, again, to get initial feedback. > In case i didnt mention it before, i am part of the design and UX > teams. :DFantastic! Thanks again.
Patch Set 1:(1 comment)Looks good to me, a nitpick below.

Patch Set 1:> by the way "include-what-you-use" should report these as well, > although not in windows-only code yet because we'd need to be able > to build with clang on windows first. >  > see also easy-hack  https://bugs.documentfoundation.org/show_bug.cgi?id=42949Thanks Michael. Good to know. The reason I wrote this script is because I have another patch that improves pch generation (a rewrite of update_pch in python that updates every single pch in the codebase in a few seconds). It was obvious to me that to improve the pch generation to make builds faster I had to deal with the problem of conflicting headers (that are excluded from pch) and required headers (that will break the build if left out). This script solves the latter problem, so now what is included in pch headers is purely to accelerate builds, not to prevent the build from breaking.Will submit the update_pch script and updated pch files sometime soon, as time permits.

You were complaining about unreliable jenkins results > yourself.Thanks for the review. You mean I should disable it by default?The tests are designed to be as stable as possible (obviously). I only submitted when I was confident enough that they won't cause immediate instability (evident from the commit message and the test design/code). What I'm saying in the message is that there are no strong guarantees from the OS, and the tests _can_ fail (doesn't mean _will_ fail). I just don't know how often. I suspect they will not fail any more than other fragile tests fail, and far less often than jenkins fails randomly (I know because I tested extensively).I think we should disable only when there is evidence that it is not stable.I will replace the static buffer with dynamic one.

Patch Set 5:(2 comments)> don't really know what this does :-), but it has a unit test and > the build passesI know this has already been merged but Laurent asked me to look at this (and only now I am getting a chance)As far as I understand it ('cause I am not so familiar with this stuff either and anything I did know I have mostly forgotten) this looks like in general the correct approach.There needs to be a version bump for the binary format, there is already a version bump prepared (that was missed) see http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/s?refs=B_EXT_IMG_VERSION&project=core  E.g. the binary format was supposed to be changed to B_EXT_IMG_VERSION but it never happened, probably it was around the time of openoffice->libreoffice or something I can't remember, I do remember we were waiting for a new release to bump the version.  I think all that is required is to adjust http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/basic/source/classes/sbxmod.cxx#1809 (or get rid of that method and adjust the caller (in scriptcont) to pass the current binary format versionplease see https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=64377needless to say that stuff needs to be retested too (but it would be good to get it in)It is of course possible to juggle the version numbers (and code) in such away to implement just this new update to the binary format (and skip enabling aoo#64377) that's fine too, but... I think a version bump in necessary in anycase

Patch Set 5:Hi Ashod - is it -really- the case that our periodic timers don't work  =) I'd be really worried if that was so - we need a unit test for it. Any chance you can create one ?Thanks !

Patch Set 5:> Hi Ashod - is it -really- the case that our periodic timers don't > work  =) I'd be really worried if that was so - we need a unit test > for it. Any chance you can create one ? > Thanks !Depends what you mean by "work." The timers of course _do_ work, but that is not the problem I'm fixing. I'm fixing the issue with high idle CPU utilization. Periodic timers should reset their start time so that they re-fire only after the duration has expired. The issue, I found, is that Timer thinks it's ready to fire again at the next tick. Ticks come in for the _soonest_ next timer delay (this is because we really have only one system timer callback, and we need it to fire for the next timer in the queue). In the worst case they come in immediately (after 1ms) and in those cases Timer thinks it's ready to fire again, which it does. This doesn't cause any obvious problems, other than CPU utilization where there shouldn't be any (because Timer handles background jobs, like spellchecking, which wastes some CPU and returns, but the waste is proportional to the document size and number of documents open).It is clear from the code that nowhere is the start-time reset. Of course I had the luxury of debugging and seeing what was happening, but the code and my comments make it almost trivial to trace the variable in question and see that without changing it, it will trick Timer into firing again. (See Timer::ReadyForSchedule where mnUpdateTime is used.)I can add unittest for this but, from experience, timers are not reliable enough to trap them within a reasonable time frame from make the test meaningful. On a non-realtime OS, they come with no guarantees. And they are less consistent across a number of OSes. We can have a crude "test fire once" and "test don't fire too soon" but it's harder to have "fired too late." Also, it's much harder to simulate the myriads of jobs we have and the arbitrary periods of each (and how they overlap).I'll give it a shot, but applying and running a large document with this 1 liner will show that the idle CPU utilization does go to 0.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Verified+1Looks good.I think this needs some follow-up though. The configuration's default "Use formula syntax" doesn't match the actual default value used in INDIRECT() now. The configuration dialog probably has to check also mbHasStringRefSyntax and if not set present the "Calc A1 | Excel A1" setting selected instead.Also, there are a few places left where meStringRefAddressSyntax is set directly, e.g. sc/source/core/tool/formulaopt.cxx in ScFormulaCfg::UpdateFromProperties() that doesn't handle CONV_A1_XL_A1 and doesn't set via SetStringRefSyntax() so mbHasStringRefSyntax remains unset. Also in ScFormulaCfg::ImplCommit() CONV_A1_XL_A1 is not handled.In sc/source/filter/oox/workbookhelper.cxx in WorkbookGlobals::initialize() has aCalcConfig.meStringRefAddressSyntax = getConvention(xDocProps); where getConvention() returns CONV_OOO if the generator was not Microsoft. That looks odd and maybe should be CONV_A1_XL_A1 instead.

Patch Set 1:This patch needs a careful review by someone who understands how redlines and SPRMs work.  I don't understand this code - I just figured out something that fixed my problem and tried to make it as targeted as possible.  I'm not really sure of the implications - it just didn't seem to do anything bad to my sample document....  The biggest problem is that this is called at the end of EVERY cell, regardless of whether it is touching a redline. I couldn't figure out how to recognize when that occurs.	What I think is happening is that the WriteCR attribute from the PREVIOUS cell is being attached to the redline group and merged together.   However, although the IncludeEndOfParaCRInRedlineProperties() method seems to try to handle these things, it isn't catching this case.	How to write a automated compile testcase for this fix is beyond me since I don't understand what is happening deep in the code, and I can only see the problem when looking at the document in Word.  Several manual testcases are attached to the bug report.

Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1OK - false alarm.  Sorry - I'm making false connections in my mind about what the old code actually did, and all of the situations it messed up.  The old code DID only handle increasing sequential links - just sometimes it ran across the bigger one first, and then matched with the first higher/lower one that it came across.  It was MY example that actually was numbered in the reverse order and so wouldn't have worked on the old logic.  OK - shouldn't be a regression after-all.  And your test document loaded/looked fine.

Patch Set 6:OK - false alarm.  Sorry - I'm making false connections in my mind about what the old code actually did, and all of the situations it messed up.  The old code DID only handle increasing sequential links - just sometimes it ran across the bigger sequence first, and then reversed the logic to matched with the lower one.  It was MY example doc (albeit vml) that actually was numbered in the reverse order and so wouldn't have worked on the old logic. And your test document loaded/looked fine.  So in my mind I'm combining all that plus some things I saw (can't remember all where) about mso-layout-flow-alt indicating a reverse sequence - where the highest number starts the chain instead of ends the chain, but although this alt-flow is put in the grabbag, it is never used.  In the end the lack of reverse chaining is still a (potentially) missing feature, not a regression.

Patch Set 7:(1 comment)More thoughts:* Do not introduce a function returning std::vector into the stable URE API.  Things like libstdc++'s __cxx11 namespace show that std entities /do/ change in ways that would make it unnecessarily complicated for us to maintain backwards compatibility in the URE API.* That implies that getElementsAsVector should be #ifdef LIBO_INTERNAL_ONLY (and in a PRIVATE_* section in gcc3.map).* That, however, implies that external code needs to continue to call getElements, which now incurs a performance impact (as it always needs to call the equivalent of comphelper::containerToSequence).  Not sure the (assumed?) performance improvements of switching from Sequence to vector justify that (assumed) performance degradation.

Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2I do not think we want to add support for everyone's favourite compression method... gz is okay, as it is handled by zlib, which we already use. System liblzma is only useful for Linux distro packages.

Patch Set 4:@KoheiIt seems SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl() is called once after the Calc csv import-dialog finishes, but it does not reload the file as it finds that pImp->m_pInStream is non NULL. I tried printing the first line from pImp->m_pInStream from SfxMedium::GetInStream() and found that it always prints the compressed(raw) data, both before and after the text filter detect code. So it seems that our modification of XInputStream variable embedded in media descriptor inside textfilter detect() does not reflect in the SvStream* type var "pImp->m_pInStream" inside SfxMedium. Is this behavior consistent with the design ?

Patch Set 4:@Kohei : After textdetect filter call, in the call to SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl()both pImp->xStream and pImp->xInputStream are populated. At line number 2340, in this method, pImp->m_pInstream is populated from pImp->xStream rather than pImp->xInputStream due to the order of if-else statements. I think that pImp->xStream is uncompressed as I did not set MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM property in media descriptor in the detect code.The csv import dialog uses the xInputStream directly where as the ScDocShell::ConvertFrom() uses SvStream from SfxMedium::GetInStream()I tried to reverse the order of if-else statement in SfxMedium::GetMedium_Impl() (starting at line number 2340). But soon realized that it is not correct as1) it breaks some unit tests (import of pdf files failed)2) Though the spreadsheet now shows uncompressed data, the csv import dialog shows empty data !. I thought it was due to file stream position set to the end, but seeking the pImp->xInputStream to the beginning did not solve that.So I reverted this change and instead tried assigning to both MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM and MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM properties in the textdetect filter code as follows :uno::Reference<io::XStream> xStreamDecompressed(new utl::OStreamWrapper(*pDecompressedStream));                                                                                                    aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_STREAM()] <<= xStreamDecompressed;                                                                                                                                aMediaDesc[MediaDescriptor::PROP_INPUTSTREAM()] <<= xStreamDecompressed->getInputStream();This change seems to work, no unit test failed, and uncompressed data in both spreadsheet and csv import dialog. I will push this patch to gerrit shortly.

Patch Set 1:(All mentioned C++ functions are member of SCInterpreter)Creating a slightly different version of GetNumberSequenceArray() will make functions like WORKDAY.INTL and NETWORKDAYS.INTL to work with inline text arrays representing dates.But it will prevent e.g. function MEDIAN to work with inline text arrays representing dates, which is the case with Excel.That's why I used one version of GetNumberSequenceArray(). I wanted to make all functions using GetSortArray() and GetNumberSequenceArray() to accept inline text arrays representing dates. I made attachments for both tdf89872 and tdf88547 containing a bit of both types of function calls.These attachments give the same result in Excel as in Calc (with this patch set).I have not tested Excel with inline text arrays like {"1","3","4"}; my patch will accept this.IMHO the sort of patch you suggest will keep a difference between Excel and Calc and therefor will lead to a bug report sooner or later. Patch Set 2:Please note: First, bug 90447 has not been marked as "NEW" yet - only partially verified by a third party.Second, the ::End() function really should be fully re-written, but that is way beyond my current skills, and also would be a "design from scratch" effort.  The big problem is that it changes the current cursor position and so "flashes around a lot" especially when multiple tabs are involved.  Instead the function should quietly compute the cell.Third, I bundled two related items into one bug report (my bad).  This fixes the ::end function.  The ::find function does work quietly, but adds a ->Select() at the end of the function.  The select could (should?) easily be commented out, but I assume that will break some people's code or something else.  Is it worth breaking bad vb coding to make the program act more like Excel in this case?  I'd like whoever reviews this code to comment on that.

Patch Set 3:the A?=B syntax is a way in Makefileto doif A has no value then A=Belse keep A's valuethat way one can export A= before the invocation of makeand the user value is honored.seehttps://www.gnu.org/software/make/manual/html_node/Setting.html#index-_003f_003d-1The proper way is to run the pch script from Makefile, in which case A would be set naturally with the appropriate value.Note our makefile support the target 'cmd' for that very purpose:make cmd cmd="./bin/update_pch.sh [..]"which avoid the evil use of get_config_variables
Patch Set 3:I removed the evil get_config_variables and added a comment to hint at using make.

Patch Set 2:Thanks Miklos. Done as suggested.Two notes: Although I don't think the parallelism of the build is really related to this, I agree that this approach is cleaner and is a good starting point. Later we can add command line argument to override the parallelism to override the build parallelism.Second, for me at least, the PARALLELISM entry in the config_host.mk looks weird. There is an extra question-mark after the name (a non-printable character?) and the next entry has an extra space. Not sure what's going on. In any event, I added a fallback to '0' so xargs would decide the number level of parallelism if we fail to get a sane result from config_host.mk.export PARALLELISM?=20 export GNUCOPY=C:/Bin/cygwin64/bin/cp

Patch Set 2:It's standard Makefile syntax. :-)Any reason you use "grep "^ *export PARALLELISM=" config_host.mk | sed -e "s/[^=]*=//"" instead of bin/get_config_variables? . ./bin/get_config_variables PARALLELISMwould do what you need, I guess.
