Patch Set 6:I checked the run-time behavior and it works very well.  And I checked the ODF attribute name, and I *think* that, although there are several other names we could re-use for this purpose, repeat-item-labels is probably reasonable.Now, 2 things remain.  One is that we need a new unit test to cover this new feature.  Hopefully you can pick one of the existing test cases in ucalc_pivottable.cxx as a model and add a new test case.  Another one is that, because we are adding a new attribute that's not yet in the ODF standard, we need to use a different namespace other than 'table:', to make sure that when we export the document it will be a valid ODF.  I *think* you can use either XML_NP_CALC_EXT or XML_NP_LO_EXT for this.  Eike, do you have any advice on which namespace to use?That's all I have to say on this.  Great work!

Patch Set 1:(1 comment)utl::ConfigItem for one internally caches the state of the configuration data it manages, and for another notifies any of its listeners upon PutProperties().  Therefore, replacing (part or whole of) a ConfigItem's functionality with direct officecfg::... API calls is not a trivial task.  Are you certain that it is sound here?

Patch Set 1:Hi Stephan,so, it seems they use ConfigItem to call GetProperties, GetNodeNames, ReplaceSetProperties and PutProperties.All them manages endless Sequences to get/set configuration options. By using directly officecfg we can get and set these values. Also, all these calls to ConfigItem methos are done in one place, so, the initial get and the following set are always done in methods from cfgitem. So we can safely (in theory) to cleanup the ConfigItem inheritance of SmMathConfig.Maybe I can missed something, but it seems to be the actual scenario.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2So - it seems to me that with all our (well Caolan's really ;-) hard work on coverity fixing, my hope is that this prop handler should be able to cope with arbitrary broken / truncated / partially written / fuzzed & mangled data streams. Certainly, far better than we did in the past; and where they fail that is a handler bug we can fix separately.So - I'm strongly in favour of a more friendly locking mode; the alternative: of read-only opened files, when someone else is just browsing that directory; or worse - of making everyone's directory browsing slow by needlessly locking things remotely while they browse is pretty horrible =)It seems to fix a key MIMO issue seen in the wild, and is plausible, so I'm in favour =)

Patch Set 1:In the previous code, the zoom scale factor was ONLY saved when the zoom type was percent mode, not page width, full page etc.  I kept that logic intact - as it seems more correct logically.However, Microsoft Office ALWAYS saves the zoom scale factor.  So it could also be correct to do it that way.  That would at least help out any implementations (like LO before this patch) that import zoom percent but not zoom type.In the end, zoom type takes precedence over zoom factor, so I don't think it is important which way we choose, especially since very few people seemed interested in the bug (i.e. no bibisect).

Patch Set 3:Hi Mikos, I don't understand how export tests were done. That's why I did it in a more conservative way, putting it in import tests.It is my concern that numbering types are not one to one mapping. A sequence like import, export, import lose information by nature. For example there are many cases fallback into NUMBER_LOWER_ZH. However it seems that the patchset for rtfexport can compile ( did it ever make check? ) , It contradict my guess.

Patch Set 3:When designing the framework, we had two basic ideas:- interesting document models are easier to be loaded from some format, than building them from code- checking an in-memory document model is reasonably easy (usually by using the UNO API), at least easier than asserting a written file (think of manually checking a binary .doc result)That's why for export tests, we do an import->export->import sequence. That ensures that the doc. models can be still stored in a file, allows asserting the result using the UNO API, and still export problems are detected. (I'm just re-stating what's in sw/qa/extras/README, just in case for some reason that file is not clear.) Hopefully this makes it clear how export tests are done. :-)Regarding loosing data during import/export: sure, sometimes that's necessary when e.g. our numbering types and MSO's numbering types do not match. In your case, the provided tests passed just fine when also the exporter got included in the chain, that's why I changed that. As long as it passes, it's safe to change, and it ensures that your export improvements won't break in the future silently. ;-)

Patch Set 2:So UPD has been computed as the somewhat silly  10^(floor(log_10(max(minor, 1)))+1)*major + 10*minorever since 74bd1f57b56918a3ef5f27aa2565397a4c6e85e1 (and before that had been manually tracked as something like RSCVERSION=350 in solenv/inc/minor.mk).  This clearly has drawbacks if ever minor > 9.So, instead of carefully mimicking that silly formula via application of OString::number and OString::toInt* to integer literals, I would suggest turning to a more sane formula instead, like  1000*major + 10*minor(Whether it is better or worse to include micro in that formula I don't know.)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1On the question of whether it is sufficient to resolve the problem: please test it. Create a query (with an outer join) in design view, and then switch to SQL view. Is the "{ OJ" in lower case? If not, "git grep -w OJ -- connectivity/ dbaccess/" gives this interesting match:dbaccess/source/ui/querydesign/QueryDesignView.cxx:                                            aStr += "{ OJ ";This indiscriminately puts all tokens in lower case; however fdo#84073 is about the "{ }" escapes *only* (which are not in the SQL standard, they are an ODBC / JDBC escape/extension), not the whole SQL standard. I'd rather we changed only the ODBC/JDBC escapes: { oj ... } // outer join { ts .. } // timestamp { d .. } // date { t .. } // time(any other I'm forgetting?)The date/time ones seem to be in (if not in sqlflex.l)connectivity/source/commontools/DateConversion.cxx:                            aRet.appendAscii("{TS '");

So I created another "if (aStr.isEmpty())" block(BTW, what about SQL_TOKEN_CUME_DIST comment?)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1I think that is more convenient and expressive, delegate the cause to the constructor instead of use a helper class that calls the initCause method, a new constructor could take the cause and another one the detail message and the cause. In any case, this proposal offers a great improvement.

Patch Set 1:"I would suggest to generate an additional three ctors that each take a first argument Throwable cause"That would cause a minor compile-time incompatibility, in that a call  E(null)would now be ambiguous, but arguably such a call had always bordered on beeing illegal (as it sets the UNO css.uno.Exception string Message member to null, and null is not among the java.lang.String values that are valid UNO string representations), is probably rare in practice, only causes a compile-time and not a run-time problem, and is trivially fixed in the source code.  (But technically, it would make the commit an [API CHANGE] again.)

Patch Set 1:Actually this is incompatible with the pre 4.1 behavior (that's right - it's broken since 4.1, and no one ever complained until now). For example, for the edit verb a user could use in a macro both -1 (which is correct) and 65535. Of course we can emulate the old behavior by simply casting back SfxUInt16Item::GetValue() to signed, but I wonder whether it's a good idea to carry this ancient bug (as it seems there's no much user code that depends on it).

Patch Set 7:i wonder what is the goal here?it is utterly pointless to build the LO bundled python as "universal" in any way, since the rest of the LO code supports only a single architecture anyway, so there are only downsides, i.e. it is a waste of space.IIRC the only reason why the --enable-universalsdk parameter is used is that it is the _only_ way to get python to build against the SDK, and not random stuff in /usr/include etc; it is somehow tangled up with building universal binaries in python's build system but that is (imho) a deficiency of python's build system.did you see the silly changes to fix that up in external/python3/python-3.3.0-darwin.patch.1?

Patch Set 1:Miklos: In ww8atr.cxx i have made sure to get the value using GetAuthorField().I have a doubt for authfld.cxxI will undo my changes as you suggested but in SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand, GetAuthorField() is called for AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER irrespective of what is passed as eField which i think should be changed.In DocxAttributeOutput::EndField_Impl, ExpandField is called with AUTH_FIELD_TITLE which then calls ConditionalExpand but ConditionalExpand returns OUString as per AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER which is wrong and should be changed.I have the patch ready...Could you please confirm?

Patch Set 1:Mkilos:I am making changes in:	 OUString SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand(ToxAuthorityField eField) constAs per changes:-sRet += pEntry->GetAuthorField(AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER); will be changed to sRet += pEntry->GetAuthorField(eField);I have calculated the impact of SwAuthorityField::ConditionalExpand:-a)ConditionalExpand is called from OUString SwAuthorityField::Expand() const with argument as AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER so my change in ConditionalExpand will not affect existing behaviour.http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/fields/authfld.cxx#543b)ConditionalExpand is called from OUString SwField::ExpandField(bool const bCached, ToxAuthorityField eField) constwith the argemunt as eField.The eField argument in SwField::ExpandField is a default argument having value AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER only so my change will not affect existing behaviour.http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/fields/fldbas.cxx#397The only possibiliy that is left is what if SwField::ExpandField is called with both the arguments and the second argument is not AUTH_FIELD_IDENTIFIER??I have checked the callers of SwField::ExpandField and came to know that it is called with only one argument and hence second augumrnt will be taken as default so there will not be any issue.The only time SwField::ExpandField is called with two parameters is for Citation only.so i request you to please consider this.Apologies for making you read so much.

Patch Set 2:the vintage implementation did not work with coretext since it rely on changing the text color _after_ the layout occured so bassically that had no effectand yes this was just to restore the support or outline for now it is not meant to be the answer yet to everything...Bold is handled at the font attribute level.. and indeed outline + bold 'emulation' does not work... it can't really since the emulation of outline and bold use the same attribute but one with negative value the other with a positive value... you can't have both.The whole layout object is poorly designed... and rewriting it is on my to-do list.. but there are plenty of special case and a variety of use cases in different platform to take into account.. so that will take time...

Patch Set 9:``1/ do not break other platform code'' Agree with this, I don't like to break working code.``2/ do no shift the burden on maintenance back onto other platforms'' Disagree here, becasue it is related to SAL (software abstraction layer), which purpose is to provide independency from any particular platform.``3/ keep it clear that whatever hack is needed is for that purpose, so that we can clean it up easily later'' Thanks for telling fairly that my work can be easily removed.

Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1I still don't see how you expect HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN and HAVE_MEMALIGN to propagate to the compilations. (Of course, you don't notice if/that they don't in your compilations, as you care only for the cases where they are not defined.)The OOo/LO codebase is full of delusions of grandeur and misleading names for various bits and pieces. Don't take the "system abstraction layer" expansion of the "sal" acronym too literally.Of course want it to be easy to remove your code at some point. This codebase is 20 years old now, and I expect (fear?) that it will be around after 20 years still, too. Do even you expect PowerPC Macs and OS X 10.5 to be around any more at that point in time?

Patch Set 11:It is misleading to claim that the code would "blindly guess" the availability of posix_memalign() (and others). The LibreOffice code is *not* portable to arbitrary platforms. We *know* what it is portable to. We depend on totally machine- and OS-dependent assembler code, for chrissake. We enumerate the platforms it has been ported to in the configure file (and elsewhere). Thus I think it does not make things any worse to not suddenly start pretending we are oh so portable and must do all the autoconf way for this one thing.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1I don't think this is good.  If we offer a general-purpose, low-level rtl_allocateAlignedMemory that promises to return aligned memory, it should not be able to silently return non-aligned memory.  (If you're confident that it is OK for your 10.5 port to silently return non-aligned memory, then please make this conditional exactly on that 10.5 port.)

Patch Set 3:"can you please suggest solution for Darwin/OSX where are no posix_memalign nor memalign?"  Recent OS X does have posix_memalign, so it apparently only is a problem for the 10.5 port.  As I wrote, "If you're confident that it is OK for your 10.5 port [...], then please make this conditional exactly on that 10.5 port," i.e., I'd suggest using the usual MAC_OS_X_VERSION_MAX_ALLOWED < 1060 instead of a newly introduced HAVE_POSIX_MEMALIGN."Also, don't forget that there're another platforms where posix_memalign is not available."  Which relevant ones are that?  And they potentially offer some similar functionality already that we could use, like in the Android case."When this memory.c has been introduced? Why? For what purpose?"  See git log.

Patch Set 3:doug: "Also, don't forget that there're another platforms where posix_memalign is not available."this is in unx/*Unixes that are not Posix are not really a concern these days.Windows, the usual offender in that field, _has_ a _aligned_mallocso, no none of the supported platform have issues with that..Furthermore, jsut because something is 16 bytes aligned, does not make it conformant to memalign... of course malloc return a value that is addressable so typically at least a multiple of sizeof(void*)but posix_memalign is meant to deal with : I need page-aligned memory and this sort of things.

Patch Set 9:the build failure is not due to this patch, I'll reschedule when it becomes available again now that the build failure is fixed in master.Yes, the GetGraphics returns NULL when there is no available graphics available for use by the caller. e.g. because there is a limited number of them which can be in use at any given time and they are all already in use. Some implementations can hand out a new one always, which is the simple case, some can have only one "checked out" at a time, and most have a pool where there can have a limited bunch in place at any one time.

Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1This isn't going to fly I believe. e.g.pGraphics /*= oldgraphics*/pGraphics = GetGraphics() becomesif (AcquireGraphics())    pGraphics = GetGraphics()so if we couldn't acquire graphics we have pGraphics pointing to the oldone, not NULL, so the expectations of the code have changed and I'm unconvinced that every case is handled correctly. Far simpler and safer would be to just rename GetGraphics to AcquireGraphics, which solves the problem and is safer.Also, one commit for one problem, mixing indendation changes, sal_Bool to bool and extra problems in one patch is making it very hard to unpick what's going on in any given commit.Leave this patch with me a while and I'll turn it into a GetGraphics->AcquireGraphics change and split out some of the additional bits in separate commits.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1Thank you for the patch!  I wonder - do we have to introduce a new flag?  Isn't it enough to re-use the GETFOCUS_TAB here too?Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing?  Or is that unrelated?The rest is nitpicking :-) - if we really need GETFOCUS_F6, it should be 0x0800, not 0x1000.  PreNotify() should return true's, not 1's.Thanks so much - and sorry the review took so long; -1's for now, hope that's OK, please set back to 0 when you upload a new patch at some stage.

Patch Set 3:>> Also about removing if(GETFOCUS_TAB & GetGetFocusFlags()) - what now happens when you click there; won't it lead to extra focusing and unfocusing? Or is that unrelated?> Yes, you are right. I will revert this change and will add a more explicit solution which will select item just when it is actually necessary. Unfortunately ImplGrabFocus() can't be used outside vcl, which would be a simple way (e.g. using ImplGrabFocus(GETFOCUS_F6) inside BackingWindow too).I was wrong. It seems mouse click doesn't lead to GetFocus() call (maybe that's why there is no a GETFOCUS_MOUSE flag?) so for simplicity I keep at the first version (select first item in all case when GetFocus is called).

Patch Set 2:I did three changes:(1) JobExecutor did not implement XComponent, so would not be notified pre-exit by a component context/service manager dispose, but would only release its resources during atexit, with all the dreaded consequences.  It now implements XComponent (via cppu::WeakComponentImplHelper4, which unfortunately required some more changes, due to framework's ill tendency to roll everything its own).(2) The "Prior to..." comment should only come after the descriptive first sentence in the documentation of theJobExecutor.idl.(3) No idea what that OOo.jcs file is exactly, but it is binary and I at least routinely ignore it when doing any sort of mass changes, so reverted that again.
Patch Set 2:And no, this is no incompatible API change.  Deprecating a published service is not considered an incompatible change.

Patch Set 1: Do not mergePlease try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.First, you are changing minimum SDK version we are not interested in ÔÇö┬áthere is a sweet ICS future, it is more wise to move forward instead of backward. Second, changing target SDK should be supported via build servers to not fail. Third, we are not interested at moment in switching from ABS to ABC because LO Android port uses ABS anyway and, again, this should be supported via build servers. Fourth, SettingsActivity after your change wouldnÔÇÖt have an action bar on pre-Honeycomb versions.I agree with you that ABS ÔåÆ ABC migration makes sense but there is a *really low* percentage of users using Gingerbread. It makes a very little sense for me to swap dependencies for things that just work for platform version which *potentially* could be dropped.

Patch Set 1:> Please try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.This is an atomic commit. Splitting that up would result in unbuildable project/mix of abs and android support lib. Not what you want.And did you even bother to look at the patch? All those changes are trivial, basically replacing "Sherlock" with "Compat" or similar> First, you are changing minimum SDK version we are not interested in ÔÇö there is a sweet ICS future, it is more wise to move forward instead of backward.Changing the minimum version doesn't impact use of new ICS features at all. That's what the support libraries are for. ActionBarSherlock previously, and the default android support library in the proposal.You fail to mention what ICS features are lost by that, so please elaborate. And of course one doesn't need to lower it - but why artificially limiting the usable devices when there is no reason?> Second, changing target SDK should be supported via build servers to not fail.No idea what you mean by that. Target SDK is the version that is definitely supported, i.e. in this case the version that runs on a device I personally own, did personally test with. But again, no biggie to leave that at present values.> Third, we are not interested at moment in switching from ABS to ABCWho is "we"?> because LO Android port uses ABS anyway and,How is the LO Android port related to the Impress Remote? The remote(s) have already been decoupled translation wise, release-schedule wise, so I fail to see how the remote is bound to the Android port.Again the changes are small, the android support libraries stack up easily to support newer features.You mentioned that newer versions have nice features and you'd rather drop support for older devices: using the android support libs makes that easy. In Fact the ABS one already used the v4 support library itself.> again, this should be supported via build servers.And again no idea what you mean by that. If you mean it should be buildable by ant/using the makefiles and not by using Eclipse, you should see that I also updated the makefile.I didn't bother to add a check whether the v7 support library has been installed on the machine, as it is not built as part of LO anyway, and the error message will be pretty obvious in that case....If you insist, I can also add configure checks. Or do the easy way as with the abs and check it into the repo.> Fourth, SettingsActivity after your change wouldnÔÇÖt have an action bar on pre-Honeycomb versions.It will.> I agree with you that ABS ÔåÆ ABC migration makes sense but there is a *really low* percentage of users using Gingerbread.I didn't change it because I wanted to lower the minimumSDK, that was just the result of the lint check that this is the minimum that the code uses.> It makes a very little sense for me to swap dependencies for things that just work for platform version which *potentially* could be dropped.I don't care about the minimum SDK, so don't fixate on that.  I did swap dependencies for the contrary, to make it easier to extend later with new features. Even the author of the ABS wrote that ABS has done its job, that with the android support lib v7 there is no reason to use ABS anymore. That of course doesn't mean one should swap components, never change a running system yadda,yadda, but the remote is small, the change as a whole is small, so it is (IMHO) a sensible thing to do.You also state on the one-hand pre honeycomb (aka gingerbread) would look different, but on the other hand you're willing to just drop support for gingerbread completely. So I fail to see how this then is a concern regarding this patch.

Patch Set 2:please be serious.Nowhere does this state it is about dropping support for pre-honeycomb.I say it is OK that instead of "ALL CAPS" they get "All Caps" (or whatever casing the string is actually present in the xml/translations).So if you insist that all-caps for those entries is a must, just have translators provide them in ALL CAPS and you don't see any difference.I personally dislike all-caps, and wouldn't mind also removing that from the styledefinition for newer devices.

Patch Set 2:While I appreciate that you took your time to comment on my patches, I cannot take your comments seriously.In the other patch you say it's fine to completely ignore the interaction guidelines (not enable BT without user's consent), but here you insist that a design that was introduced on newer devices must be enforced on older devices (that you're happy to not even support at all).You also fail to explain why just keeping strings that are meant to always displayed upppercase in all-caps in the resources is no solution.

Patch Set 2:> In the other patch you say it's fine to completely ignore the interaction guidelines (not enable BT without user's consent), but here you insist that a design that was introduced on newer devices must be enforced on older devices (that you're happy to not even support at all).I see this as a visual design and UX. The visual design is defined. If Android has the Roboto font developers should consider using it instead of Comic Sans. If the whole platform uses uppercase headers developers should consider to implement it as well. On other hand the UX of Bluetooth interaction has a kind of broken state ÔÇö┬áyes, in perfect world users should enable it themselves, but why there are no dialog for disabling it themselves? Does it make sense to force user to use dialog every time one launches the app? Why user should even care about enabling or disabling Bluetooth at all? IÔÇÖm not trying to reject things I donÔÇÖt want to see or use ÔÇö┬áI try to think about better implementations which cause pleasant experience and not emotions like ÔÇ£oh this dialog againÔÇØ, ÔÇ£again this app causes battery drainÔÇØ.> You also fail to explain why just keeping strings that are meant to always displayed upppercase in all-caps in the resources is no solution.1. It is easier to translate strings when you see simple words instead of WORDS. 2. If in the future the platform remove this headers style we can just tweak the style for the text and not the text for the style.

Patch Set 1:I don't think it's the localised or not version of MSVC that matters, but the system codepage. Apparently MSVC insists that C++ source code is a valid byte sequence in the system codepage, and this UTF-8 comment is not in yours. Or something like that... I guess you don't want to change your system codepage...?

Patch Set 1:I still don't understand why we need to define any of these in out sources? What breaks if we just leave out them?

Patch Set 1:I chose the mingw mailing list entry, because there's a nice compilation of old WINVER defines, which the Microsoft documentation doesn't offer :)And at the moment we need to set WINVER because it has everywhere different values. Or we have hacks like adefd564d07a6e70cc1d9fad8febe5b434511e83 or a9fd489834b63e423d4745f0d71cf15396e3e3eb. At least for fpicker it's relevant because with 0x0501 you wouldn't get the window previews in the taskbar with Vista/7. So we need 0x0600 there, but we can't set it global to the project if we still want to support Windows XP.But you're right, after that commit many of them could be simply dropped.
Patch Set 6:i am getting loads of warnings about re-definitions of WINVER_WIN32_IE and such on current master and am seriously considering reverting this; clearly it was not finished yet

Patch Set 6:on closer examination it turns out the warnings (at least in sal) come from outdated precompiled headers - so clearly i was wrong and i take back the previous comment :)this needs a "make clean" apparently.

Patch Set 6:Sorry, I didn't mention it, but yes this does need a make clean. The patch was indeed finished.I didn't wonder about the WIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN redefinition, because this is how it's done in some other makefiles. Thanks for fixing this.Nice that this finally got into core :)

Patch Set 2:Now the settings are applied globally.And I found out how to use the macros:_WIN32_WINNT sets NTDDI_VERSION and WINVER automatically to the same version.But setting NTDDI_VERSION or WINVER sets only the macro itself.If we want to target Windows XP we need to set _WIN32_WINNT, because otherwise other SDK stuff is still included under Windows 7. But this brings us some kind of dilemma: How do we add features which are added in Windows 7 (like 9a4a84df5406cdcde1f4d23a1cea2b109998f35b)? If we set WINVER globally those features are never activated.One solution could be to check:#ifdef NTDDI_WIN7Works fine, but checks only what is supported by the Windows API (what if Win8 SDK is installed on Win7?).Maybe we should move this to the mailing list.

Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approveSo - in general in-lining headers like this is fine - assuming that we are just moving these redundant extra headers into others that are included anyway.However - looking at the number counts we do more than this:0       65      slideshow/source/inc/animationfunction.hxx104     6       slideshow/source/inc/eventmultiplexer.hxx28      2       slideshow/source/inc/expressionnode.hxx176     2       slideshow/source/inc/listenercontainer.hxx30      1       slideshow/source/inc/shapeattributelayer.hxx0       61      slideshow/source/inc/shapecursoreventhandler.hxx0       67      slideshow/source/inc/state.hxx0       59      slideshow/source/inc/userpainteventhandler.hxx0       67      slideshow/source/inc/viewrepainthandler.hxxSo - a lot more code ends up in the new headers than is removed from the old ones: where does that come from ?I'm very scared by things like:+class MutexBase+{+public:+    struct Guard : public osl::MutexGuard+    {+        explicit Guard(MutexBase const& rBase) :+            osl::MutexGuard(rBase.maMutex)+        {}+    };+    struct ClearableGuard : public osl::ClearableMutexGuard+    {+        explicit ClearableGuard(MutexBase const& rBase) :+            osl::ClearableMutexGuard(rBase.maMutex)+        {}+    };++    mutable osl::Mutex maMutex;+};Then I noticed that you just forgot to git rm 'listenercontainerimpl.hxx' that has this stuff in it.Quite why we have this 'MutexBase' class I have no idea it looks odd to me - but that's a problem for another commit =)So - anyhow - this is good. There is really not a lot of value using a pimpl pattern for classes that are internal to slideshow anyway, so - this inlining seems rather helpful.Thanks ! will push in a sec.

Patch Set 1:Circa 2009 I asked OOo development to let sysadmins disable the new database button, through a configuration parameter (default was to let users create new databases). The main reason is that in many corporations, scattered databases in desktops (such as Access or Base) are conseidered a breach in data security, uncontrollable data leak and poor data management.I beg to let sysadmins to keep installation to prevent the creation of new databases, as its is today.The configuration that hides the New Database from the dialog is here (should be added in main.xcd)----------------%<----------------------- <?xml version="1.0"?><oor:data xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:oor="http://openoffice.org/2001/registry"> <dependency file="main"/> <oor:component-data xmlns:install="http://openoffice.org/2004/installation" oor:name="DataAccess" oor:package="org.openoffice.Office">  <node oor:name="Policies">   <node oor:name="Features">    <node oor:name="Base">     <prop oor:name="CreateLocalDatabase" oor:type="xs:boolean">      <value>false</value>     </prop>    </node>    <node oor:name="Writer">     <prop oor:name="DatabaseFields" oor:type="xs:boolean">      <value>true</value>     </prop>     </node>     <node oor:name="Common">      <prop oor:name="EditDatabaseFromDataSourceView" oor:type="xs:boolean">       <value>true</value>      </prop>    </node>   </node>  </node> </oor:component-data></oor:data>----------------%<-----------------------

Patch Set 6: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedIn case I insert a page at the end of a new doc (numbered "1", physically 3 out of 3), the toolbar says "Page 1 3/3". (No idea why not "Page 1 2/2".) In this zero case, it says "Page 0/4", which is a bit confusing.OTOH I guess it improves the current situation, so let's get it in.Oh, and one more thing: in SwLayHelper::CheckInsertPage(), it's not trivial why you check the page number of the *follow* style. It would be great to have a follow-up commit that adds a comment, explaining that.

Patch Set 3: This need some tweaks before it is mergedvmiklos:I have updated all the relevant places to now use 'optional'.I still have 2 places in the code where I am not sure what the correct method should be:In 'sw/source/ui/utlui/uitool.cxx' the 'SfxUInt16Item aPageNum' is set in the function 'SwToSfxPageDescAttr'.Question is - now that 'GetNumOffset' *could* return NULL - what should be done if it *is* null ? should we set '0' to the 'SfxUInt16Item' (like I've done) ?In 'sw/source/ui/table/tabledlg.cxx' the code *used* to set the 'NumericField' with the value from the 'GetNumOffset()' function, but now it returns an optional value.so if the value is NULL - should it *not* set the NumericValue or it *should* set it, but with 0 (like I've done) ?

Patch Set 3:> vmiklos: I have updated all the relevant places to now use 'optional'.Great, thanks!> In 'sw/source/ui/utlui/uitool.cxx' the 'SfxUInt16Item aPageNum' is set in the function 'SwToSfxPageDescAttr'. Question is - now that 'GetNumOffset' *could* return NULL - what should be done if it *is* null ? should we set '0' to the 'SfxUInt16Item' (like I've done) ?If we're speaking about SwToSfxPageDescAttr(), what about just not putting the SfxPoolItem to the item set? Of course, then the consumer of that item set (insert->manual break dialog?) should handle the lack of the pool item in the set, but I guess that's logical: item missing -> "change page number" checkbox is false, item there -> "change page number" checkbox is true and the value can be even 0, if you need it.> In 'sw/source/ui/table/tabledlg.cxx' the code *used* to set the 'NumericField' with the value from the 'GetNumOffset()' function, but now it returns an optional value. so if the value is NULL - should it *not* set the NumericValue or it *should* set it, but with 0 (like I've done) ?This is the UI I was mentioning above. :) I guess null should be "checkbox false, numeric field empty", while 0 should be "checbox true, numeric field 0". Hopefully that's intuitive enough.

Patch Set 5:The vigra::copyImage is not handling copy areas in the same image so the code is checking whether the src and dst are same buffer and directing it to scaleImage which is very slow.The whole concept of pixel accessors is a huge overhead in the case of direct pixel copy (vigra::copyImage is also using pixel accessors).The idea here was to identify when direct memory copy is applicable (when src.size==dst.size && src.format==dst.format) and use direct memory block copy and not pixel wise copy.The result is 100x faster than vigra implementation.This direct copy is also handling the case when the src and dst are same buffer by copy it from bottom to top when needed and using memmove instead of memcpyabout using long or int for iterating i'm not keen on the cross platform details please advice how to do it properly.

Patch Set 1:removing commented sections is usually rather safe -- cherry-picking is somewhat robust against that. For blank lines, there is no convention on how many we should have were, so this might easily lead to a fight over that (and we shouldnt bother with that then). And brace-only changes are even more tricky: The might successfully merge -- but still be wrong.So as long as there are still germanisms in the codebase it would be awesome, if you stick to those! ;)

Patch Set 5:I mean, my understanding is:Previously, the page number offset was a single unsigned integer, where 0 meant "no restart", other values meant a restart with a positive value. This is obviously a problem if you want to have a restart with a zero value.The patch introduces bNumOffsetIsSet to signal if the page number offset is valid, this is a good move. However at other places it also starts to use -1 to signal that the page number offset is valid or not, so now we have two places storing the same info (bNumOffsetIsSet == true or page number offset == -1), which looks redundant.

Patch Set 2:Also, code like  sal_Int64 i;  any >>= i;  o << i;has the problem that, in general, >>= can return false and not write a value into i, so "o << i" could read an uninitialized i.  Some compilers warn about that.  We do know that >>= will not fail in this case, so the best is probably  sal_Int64 i = sal_Int64(); // avoid uninitialized warnings

Patch Set 1:note to self: possibly this could be replaced by sax::Converterhttp://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime appears to be very similar to xmlschema2; only difference is that http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime allows to omit elements so has the 3 additional forms YYYY     YYYY-MM   YYYY-MM-DDThh:mmTZD   that would be invalid xmlschema-2

Patch Set 1:actually i had a look at "ECMA-376 Part 1 3rd edition"(is this the relevant reference?) and it has:<quote>17.18.9ST_DateTime (Standard Date and Time Storage Format)This simple type's contents are a restriction of the W3C XML Schema dateTime datatype.</quote>which is apparently for the word processing part;then there is this about spreadsheets:<quote>18.17.4Dates and TimesEach unique instant in SpreadsheetML time is stored as an ISO 8601-formatted string, which is made up of adate component, a time component, and a timezone component.L.2.16.9.1Date Conversion for Serial ValuesAll date values stored in cells within a SpreadsheetML file are stored in the ISO 8601 format.</quote>yay - a standard with 2 different normative references for date formats!however can't find any reference to http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime  in there - where did the idea come from that that was relevant?
Patch Set 1:I don't really get what Norbert tries to say in that comment, is there something wrong in the patch?

Patch Set 3:> Lionel, any response to Michael's review?So, in general terms, the situation is that I stumbledupon broken code while doing something else and Ifixed it. Details:>> possibly this could be replaced by sax::ConverterYes, that seems desirable in the middle-to-long term.However, the name of the function referred to anotherstandard than what sax::Converter aims at, so I consideredit more prudent to fix the code "locally", referring to thestandard it purposes to implement, rather than replaceby a call to sax::Converter::parseISO8601 (or some such).Especially since I meant for this to go into our release branch(es).If someone wants to invest the time to merge this withsax::Converter, I agree it would enhance the code qualityof LibreOffice: one (hopefully not buggy) implementationof parsing date/time (that is well-tested because used much,tested by unittests, etc) instead of multiple implementationswith different bugs that possibly show up only in corner cases(and thus linger for a long time before being found).However, that someone is not me, at least not in the shortterm. > I had a look at "ECMA-376 Part 1 3rd edition" > (is this the relevant reference?)Dunno. Not my area of expertise. Looks plausible to me. > ST_DateTime (...) W3C XML Schema dateTime datatype > Dates and Time (...) SpreadsheetML (...) ISO 8601-formatted > string > Date (...) SpreadsheetML (...) stored in the ISO 8601 format > however can't find any reference to > http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime in there > where did the idea come from that that was relevant?The function is called GetDateTimeFromW3CDTF. Duckduckgoing(or Googling) for W3CDTF makes it clear that "W3CDTF" usuallymeans http://www.w3.org/TR/NOTE-datetime, so I assumed thatthis was the format the function was supposed to parse. 1) Was the W3CDTF in the function name meant as a reference     to that note? Dunno, ask its author. 2) In that case, was the reference itself an error? Michael's     research seems to indicate this would be the case.IRC (or mailing list?) discussion also basically said that as faras we know, the timezone component of this fix may not mattermuch since Microsoft Office always writes UTC (Zulu) time,so the bug would never get triggered. I think that it is stillpreferable to fix the bug to avoid that other code calls thisfunction in situations where the bug happens.So, my opinion would be:1) As proactive safety, apply this patch to master & 4-1.    (possibly an adapted part of it to 4-0; adapted because    sub-second stuff is different in 4-0: centiseconds instead    of nanoseconds) 2) In master, provided we have a volunteer to unravel that     quagmire (that knows about OOXML or willing to find out     about it), merge with sax::Converter date/time-parsing     if appropriate... If not appropriate, maybe migrate this     function to sax::Converter (along with documentation-by-     comment explaining why we need different parsers for     different formats and the difference between them), so     that our date/time-parsing code is all in one place.Since nobody clearly vetoed this patch, I'm going to push "1)" to master soon, unless someone vetoes.

Patch Set 1:Side effect?  I'm not sure. The reason why I tried to reduce the amount of virtual methods on this class is to limit the amount of surprises and makes it easier to track who's using what method.  Turning this to a virtual would add that down-side again... Once a method becomes virtual, it also becomes harder to track how it's used, and making it more difficult to debug for all users of this class.The only way to be sure there is no side effect is to test all places where this class is used.... It's hard for me to say just by looking at the code change...

(...) It'll destroy itself.and in baside3.hxx    // property browser (created by this, deleted by toolkit)    PropBrw* pPropertyBrowser;OTOH, I don't immediately see who/what ("toolkit") deletes pPropertyBrowser.So either: - these comments were wrong (and we had a leak before) - this patchset removes the "delete by toolkit" in a way that is not obvious to me - this patchset introduces a double deleteSo essentially, I'd like to clarify this before commit to 4-1.

Patch Set 2:So this script would replace occurrences of e.g.  #include "sal/config.h"with  #include <sal/config.h>The latter is wrong, or at least less portable than the former (and thus the script should never be used to modify the code base).  The <...> form is for standard headers (provided through the compiler), while the "..." form is for arbitrary source files (provided by the compiler's client).  (The use of "header" in the Standard does not necessarily reflect colloquial usage of that term.  The exact mechanisms are implementation-defined in any case, but the <compiler/platform> vs. "client" is the general idea.  And I know that lots of places in the code erroneously use the <sal/config.h> form, but that doesn't mean that it is good; it just never bothered anybody enough in practice to fix it.)

Patch Set 2:Stephan, thanks for clearing that up. So probably we should just invert the conversion the script does, to fix those <sal/..> -> "sal/..." stuff. Like it's obvious in sal/inc/pch/precompiled_sal.hxx. Would that be ok?

Patch Set 4:I am not really happy about the commit message. Reading it, it is hard to understand what effect the patch actually has. Please don't use passive voice. Write simple, imperative statements describing what effect the patch has.If you need to refer to the behaviour of code before the patch, be explicit, as in "Foo previously did bar", not "The way it works now". (Saying how something works "now" is ambiguous, does it mean "now, after this patch" or "now, before this patch".)Instead of "saving to docx is fixed", say "fix saving to docx". (But does the patch really fix saving to docx in general, was that broken? Or do you mean compared to a previous version of the patch? In that case, no need to mention it, once this goes into git, any iterations ("patch sets") it had in gerrit is irrelevant.

Patch Set 2:Hi Eike, I was unable to reply on the thread of the inline comments so I preferred to write those things here:If I don't make the changes in sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx, then on doing 'make' I get an error :/home/elixir/libo/sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx: In static member function ÔÇÿstatic void ScXMLConverter::GetStringFromFunction(rtl::OUString&, ScSubTotalFunc, bool)ÔÇÖ:/home/elixir/libo/sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx:145:11: error: enumeration value ÔÇÿSUBTOTAL_FUNC_SELECTION_COUNTÔÇÖ not handled in switch [-Werror=switch]cc1plus: all warnings being treated as errors .with --enable-werror [ I enabled this, since warnings are no good and mac crashes with warnings is what I've learnt through irc conversations ].So handling ÔÇÿSUBTOTAL_FUNC_SELECTION_COUNTÔÇÖ in switch became necessary.The rest of xml file changes follow this change.And definitely I shall take care of indentation. :)I small doubt: Should the hidden rows be counted in 'Selection count', i.e. if the row was hidden, its value should be added or not?ThanksPrashant

Patch Set 2:> If I don't make the changes in sc/source/filter/xml/XMLConverter.cxx, then on doing 'make' I get an error :As discussed on IRC, handle that with an empty case statement.> And definitely I shall take care of indentation. :)Good :-)> I small doubt: Should the hidden rows be counted in 'Selection count', i.e. if the row was hidden, its value should be added or not?Good question.. I think they should be treated the same as for the otherfunction cases so that Count2 and SelectionCount deliver the same resultif all selected cells are filled with data.

Patch Set 1:This change is related to columns in text sections, not columns for pages. I guess page columns are not exported to HTML because there is really no generally applicable way of doing that; HTML pages do not have fixed height like pages in Writer do.To test this you need to- Open a new empty Writer document- Choose Insert -> Section- Go to Columns tab and type in a number, 3 for example, click Insert.- now you can see the little grey section markers, paste some long text inside those.- save as HTML, you should end up with a HTML document that has a MULTICOL element that contains the column count both in the old non-standard COLS-attribute and in the new css column-count attribute.PS. I hope this is the right way to respond to the review comment. I'm just trying to learn how to use this Gerrit tool.

Patch Set 2:> I think the two load options should be set to not expand vertically, looks a bit silly.The reason I did it this way was because otherwise the width of the combo box would change dynamically depending on the current selection, and I wanted to avoid that. I guess I could have set the width to a fixed value, but I wanted the GUI toolkit to do the sizing, feels more flexible.> The warning could go under the dropdown that it applies to now that nothing has to be manually moved in the code.I put it in the end because it was there in the original code, and because otherwise I would have to leave an empty row there, or have everything under it move down when it appears. I thought I should try to keep all the GUI elements static, and not jump around when a user changes something, to avoid confusion.> odfwarning never seems to appear but maybe that's a wider/theme bugIt did appear for me under Linux Mint 14 MATE, what OS are you on?

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHmm, I am not sure that I like this change. It does not create the formatting entry without any explanation. You were able to edit the unused formatting and add the range later in the past.For example, imagine that you define some formatting, forget to define the range, and press the "Add" button. You will not know why the entry was not created. You will need to select everything again and again until you find why it does not work :-)IMHO, the best solution would be to preffil the range with the current selected cell(s). For example, the DataPilot or Chart is created from the current selection by default as well.Hmm, the prefil would be annoying if you lose some older formatting  in the selected cells. In this case, I would prefer to leave the behavior as is and fix it with the error dialog for 4.1. IMHO, the behavior is more annoying with the patch than without it.BTW: I really like the conditional formatting. It is very cool and useful feature. Thanks a lot for the hard work in this area.

Patch Set 1: Verified; Looks good to me, approvedLooks ok, thanks for the patch.If you're going to do more similar changes, it'd be safer to check that the type in the cast is one of the sal_Int* types, I expect it's unlikely there would be a cast with sal_Char or sal_Bool, but if it were, changing that to number() would be incorrect.Also a small stylistic detail: Something like 'rtl::OUString::valueOf(static_cast<sal_Int32>(50))' can be actually further simplified to just "50".

Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisRemoving functions from sal.map strictly speaking requires bumping SONAME, and that is too disruptive a change for merely getting rid of those deprecated functions.Like what has been done for osl/semaphor.h, please:* do remove rtl/memory.h and rtl/source/memory.cxx,* but keep sal.map intact and add aborting stubs for the removed functions to sal/osl/all/compat.cxx* add a section to <http://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/LibreOffice4> for incompatible changes in LO 4.1, and add the removal of rtl/memory.h there* Prefix the commit message with "API CHANGE:"

Patch Set 1:Yes the problem I intended to fix is S1 exiting cleanly after S2 went into connected-pipe mode.S1's OfficeIPCThread::AreRequestsPending -> SetDowning is called after S2 connection, but before S1 receives S2 arguments which would veto downing request.Then S1 exits after receiving the next message from S2 (the args), see : // is this a termination message ? if so, terminateif (aArguments.equalsL(sc_aTerminationSequence, sc_nTSeqLength) || mbDowning) {because mbDowning is now true.So the protocol implementation does not seem flawed (except maybe that the mutex is released between AreRequestsPending/SetDowning methods).The root issue seems to be: S1 is allowed to shutdown before S2 had a chance to send its args.I'm going to look at how I can fix this...Any comments or suggestions ?

Patch Set 2:Yes, I intend to do it (btw, it seems another place in Windows startup code implements this protocol, but I believe it's unused: see desktop/win32/source/officeloader/officeloader.cxx).But I'm also fixing a related Windows only issue #33484.I hope to get both patches ready soon (what's the deadline for 4.0 ?)

Patch Set 1:"The whole check appears to be rather pointless. Do we actually use the result anywhere?"While we don't appear to be using HAVE_BOOST_UNORDERED_MAP anywhere (so setting it could be removed), we do #include "boost/unordered_map.hxx" in lots of places.  So if the system boost does not support that, we should probably error-out/switch to our boost.Forcing -std=gnu++0x for the check without coordinating that with HAVE_CXX0X (which will determine whether --std=gnu++0x is actually enabled in the build) is not really helpful, though.

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this* Setting MALLOC_PERTURB_ to zero reportedly (<http://udrepper.livejournal.com/11429.html>) disables it, so we should make sure $rndbyte is never zero.* Trying   dd if=/dev/urandom bs=1 count=1 2>/dev/null | od -tu1 | cut -s -d " " -f2does not always produce a number for me, as od outputs the 1-to-3-digit number right aligned, so cut -f2 sometimes hits "nothing" in between leading spaces.* I personally never --enable-linkoo, so it would be cool if we could put this somewhere where everybody can benefit (though I have no good idea where that would be; maybe its time to split program/ooenv in two, things that are useful for all developer runs, like MALLOC_CHECK_=2, and things specific to linkoo, like fiddling with LD_LIBRARY_PATH).

Patch Set 1:Called functions: probably setFloat / setDouble / setInt / setLong / ... or updateFloat / updateDouble / updateInt / updateLong / ...From the point of view of the driver, it should provide all of those, and the calling code chooses which one to call. Calling code can not only be LibreOffice C++ code, but also user macros, so it cannot be predicted what choice is made.When you create a table and select a DECIMAL or NUMERIC field type, don't you have the following field properties, including "Decimal places"?Entry requires: Length: Decimal places:Default value:Format example:The rounding may be because the driver tells the rest of LibreOffice that 0 decimal places are allowed. Or it may be in the configuration of the UI element. Create a form, and edit the properties of the form control: do you use a formatted field or a numeric field? In a numeric field you can set the decimal accuracy. Check what is put there.When all else fails, I single-step in a debugger from the control's "write to the database calls" into the different layers. But that is a bit heavy-weight :)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1(1 comment)The idea to merge the two threads (callback handler and tile rendering) is reasonable, but we should discuss the approach.The starvation you noticed happens because you are using the tile-queue, which is designed for... well, yes, tiles! :)It reorders the messages such that it renders tiles in large blocks first. So with heavy typing the callback messages always end up getting overtaken by tiles, which the queue explicitly favors, thereby starving callback events.So this is one problem with the current implementation. I think the tiles should have its own queue, and callbacks a separate one. The thread that pumps them would process one callback, then one tile-rendering.Another issue with combining these threads is that there will be reduction in performance. This is because before and after rendering a tile there is significant work being done that does *not* execute with the Solar lock. This code (mostly encoding to PNG) is CPU intensive and can run in parallel to other code (even to other rendering calls).Finally, I have submitted my patch (342125b8ea) to fix the missing tiles issue. Should be easier to read than describe it here (it's only +27, -6). It comes with detailed commit log too. So this approach is mostly an optimization to reduce the thread-count, but, as mentioned, we need multiple threads because we have opportunity to parallelize, and merging them will reduce performance (unless benchmark proves otherwise, of course).

Patch Set 1:Wrt. the starvation - actually that was due to the logging; we have so much debugging stuff that it was blocking considerably when writing to the console, making the queue grow.  Without that, all works fine even with the unmodified TileQueue :-)But I worked on the TileQueue too - it seems unnecessary to do all the priority shuffling when inserting, when the prioritization changes with every view switch, and instead do it only when the tile is requested - which seems to work nicely.Wrt. an own queue for tiles - that is exactly the thing that makes the synchronzation hard, as then it is necessary to synchronize between those 2 queues; which in turn kills all the advantage of 2 queues :-)Wrt. PNG compression; if we want to thread it, then let's thread just the compression - that'll make it local, more maintainable, and we can go with as many threads there as we wish (for just the PNG compression piece of code).Wrt. the 342125b8ea - thanks for that!  Unfortunately that again just adds code :-(Either way, please check https://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/online/log/?h=private/kendy/tilesandcallbacks , I'd really like to get that in...  I've tested it with several people in a session, and it performed pretty well thanks to all your work I was able to build on.
AbandonedThanks Michael. This is definitly broken and just worked out of luck, as the code actually walks the stored bookmarks instead of the whole mark list.Kind of brown paperbag patch :-(

If the page exists I would prefer references and if it doesn't what should the empty page field tell me then?Jason is right that changing page numbers is not an easy thing to do. But using offsets makes things worse. Patch Set 1:> Why do you think this is necessary?  css::uno::DisposedException is > derived from css::uno::RuntimeException (which can be thrown from > every UNO interface method).  (Also, the definition of > getPreferredVisualRepresentation in offapi/com/sun/star/embed/XVisualObject.idl > does not redundantly mention DisposedException, either; that would > be a mild argument in favour of redundantly adding it here, too.)Hi, Stephan!Actually, I was not sure it was the right thing to do, because of the inheritance from css::uno::RuntimeException.But then I checked out css::lang::IllegalArgumentException and it turned out it derives also from css::uno::RuntimeException.You can verify it here: workdir/UnoApiHeadersTarget/udkapi/normal/com/sun/star/lang/IllegalArgumentException.hdlSo I thought that we should list all exceptions

Patch Set 1:> But then I checked out css::lang::IllegalArgumentException and it > turned out it derives also from css::uno::RuntimeException. > You can verify it here: workdir/UnoApiHeadersTarget/udkapi/normal/com/sun/star/lang/IllegalArgumentException.hdl > So I thought that we should list all exceptionsIllegalArgumentException is covered by what I explained in the parenthetical remark "Also, the definition of getPreferredVisualRepresentation in offapi/com/sun/star/embed/XVisualObject.idl does not redundantly mention DisposedException, either; that would be a mild argument in favour of redundantly adding it here, too."

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I don't think this is a good idea for the following reasons:The basic number formatter codes follow the ones Excel uses. The new 'MIMI' upon Excel export would have to be mapped to 'mm', re-reading such file the information would be lost.If there are ambiguous corner cases, those would have to be handled anyway as importing an Excel file could expose them as well, for example the code mentioned in the bug "yymmdd-ssmm" can be assigned in Excel.Adding "minutes-unambiguous" to ODF from a standard's view is suboptimal, from an ODF view the <number:minutes> element is not ambiguous. Likely a <number:minutes-unambiguous> element will not make it into the standard.
Patch Set 3:(1 comment)Looks nice to me, but I know exactly nothing about this life-cycle stuff here I'm afraid. Thanks Arnaud.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1(2 comments)So there are my two purely coding style related comments but also one about memory corruption that I need to think about.I think some dispose calls are wrong and might cause access to deleted objects. I need to follow the code a bit for this.All in all this is a great catch and should solve one of the bigger memory leaks in ODF export and OOXML import.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2I have to change my -1 to a -2. The code in XMLTableMasterPageExport.cxx is wrong. The lifecycle is messed up by these dispose calls on objects returned from getPropertyValue.This either leads to bugs (the object has been destroyed while it should not and therefore we have empty references) or even worse to access to deleted memory. Both cases are not something that I want to see in a backport.Another point is that instead of the normal public dispose methods these classes should inherit from XComponent. I'm not a fan of UNO myself but reinventing a new way to break cyclic references will only lead to problems later.Now for a way forward we need to fix the problems mentioned here and if it is safe enough we can think about a backport again. For now backporting is not an option.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2To confirm Norbert's input. I would expect such cosmetic changes to fix potential nano-aggressions ;-) to be done in the course of existing significant work to the code-base. This then avoids conflict and argument over ~irrelevances like this. "Lifecycle" is an industry standard term here encompasing creation & destruction, life & death of objects =) FWIW - the new naming is rather less clear to me.Nevertheless - if someone who is actively working on really substantial functional improvement in this area feels strongly about this, they are at liberty to change it as part of their work of course =)I'd really like to avoid us as a project getting dragged into this.Please consider abandoning your patch =)
AbandonedAs suggested, I have no real problem with cleaning this up, if we come up with a consistent and equally good naming - and it is done in the context of some larger, actually useful work =)

Patch Set 1:In general, I am personally not that convinced that adding such #ifdef DEBUG_FOO_BAR is that useful. There is a large risk that the code inside those will bit-rot anyway sooner or later. And if this code at some stage needs debugging, it is questionable whether the specific optional debug code that was perhaps useful some time ago will still be useful, or whether one will need to write more complicated or complete debugging code anyway. I would just remove it. But I am not insisting.

Patch Set 1:Hi Kendy,Please look into this and tell me if it is the right way to proceed.This throws the Unknown Property Exception as indicated below.I think we may need to call this setPropertyValue() <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/editeng/source/uno/unofield.cxx#675> instead of the one currently being called <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2152> which is throwing up an Unknown Property Exception at <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/source/core/unocore/unofield.cxx#2165> One is sw's implementation while the other is editeng's implementation. Moggi was of the opinion that the setPropertyValue() from editeng couldn't be called here. But the current one is unable to support that property (UNO_TC_PROP_TEXTFIELD_TYPE). How would it be possible to proceed?I'm influenced by this comment <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl#19> when I say the above.Also, I did a '#define UNO_NAME_TEXT_FIELD_TYPE "TextFieldType"' in <opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/sw/inc/unoprnms.hxx> taking other properties from here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/include/editeng/unonames.hxx> as an example. But I'm unsure if this is the right way to proceed.Since I've mentioned '[optional, property]long TextFieldType;' as optional in <opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/ExtendedUser.idl>, I might need a boolean to indicate when 'setPropertyValue()' must be called for each of the fields from <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/offapi/com/sun/star/text/textfield/Type.idl> in here <http://opengrok.libreoffice.org/xref/core/xmloff/source/text/txtfldi.cxx#706>. I don't think we need to call it for all 15 properties all the time. How do I use the boolean variable - like for example - how do I use it to indicate when to set EXTENDED_TIME and when not to..?Regarding the comment thread on the bug page - you'd asked what happens when I run it without removing certain stuff from content.xml . The exact same exceptions are thrown in the order of Comment 13 first and then Comment 14.On a side note, I would like to say that I'm doing this coz you'd asked me to work on LO code (with respect to GSoC) and this was a bug reported by you. Since you didn't remember filing this bug, if there is something else that you'd want me to work on, please do tell.I would have loved to work on creating MAR files (from onlineupdate module), and still do think that's the best thing to do as it would mean I would get a headstart when it comes to the actual coding period begin dates, and had sent a mail to you regarding that. But on not receivng a reply, I'd assumed you didn't want me to work on that. Please do indicate what you think I should be working on.Thanks :-)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-136270776a68c0cd0f472ebd7124c93d7936caf04 is an example on how to add a new property to a Writer field. In case the field is in shape text, then you want to do something like that in editeng, since editeng providers the shape text. The idea is that there is a C++ class that internally stores the new member, and then there is an UNO API wrapper class that exposes that in the API.I.e. no change to xmloff yet, and no change to offapi/type_reference. If you need to change the later to not break the build, that means you tried to change the API in an incompatible way, that's a no-go.

Patch Set 2:To summarize what has been discussed on IRC today:I'm not a big fan of encouraging users to use deprecated and insecure protocols (let's be honest, DDE *is* deprecated and insecure). If this is mainly about inserting links with relative paths, maybe your goals could be achieved by using relative references, i.e. =DDE("soffice"; "some/relative/path"; "SheetX.CellY")would become ='some/relative/path'#SheetXCellY'and the development effort could be targeted at implementing some UI and clipboard support for relative references and fixing outstanding relative reference issues (sometimes target doc doesn't update if source doc changes, ~/ path doesn't expand correctly etc.)

Patch Set 2:> RFC3986 specifies "~" as "unreserved" so I am not sure if it is a > good idea to use it in a FILE Uri.'~/example/doc.ods' would not be an URI, neither is 'example/doc.ods' ifthe current document's locations was $HOME, but both could be expandedto 'file:///home/username/example/doc.ods' as is already done for'example/doc.ods' or any other relative path. > Anyway, DDE fullfills all of our requirements and it is already > rsp. still working in LO. > Why should we move to a more modern but not yet working technology?It should work if just the '~/' part would be expanded to $HOME/ ifthere was no file://... protocol prefixed.

Patch Set 1:things seem to go overboard here with the abandoning of stuff.The individual patches are fine - just  because you cannot merge one before the other  doesn't make it a bad thing to have incremental approaches, as it's easier to go through smaller patches that by themselves are self-contained, than through one huge dump.So if you can review stuff individually, one after the other, then having a series of patches is perfectly fine.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I'm sorry for misleading push. I wasn't able to finish build with android when I wasbuilding 824139e28b3c9e0d448ee8abc580f06a4a434002.I expect this problem was fixed later as 14060e76e33cfb305c1469fecf7db688bf8a8858 gotbuilt fine.For building 824139e28b3c9e0d448ee8abc580f06a4a434002 I also had to disable opengl - patchin https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/23614/ but this is probably also invalid.

Patch Set 1:Is this necessary after 2428e1164b5f38da9fc2f24c5bb478e548f54a6f?Christian, sorry about the brief commit message. I was a bit upset that the headless patch was merged even though the ESC asked the author not to merge it in its current form. The opengl situation on our Android port is a bit unclear. On one hand, we disable opengl in configure, OTOH it seems we build most of the opengl code in vcl. My commit just restored that status quo, fixing the build. I also verified that the build result actually works. :-)Given that at the end Android uses cairo to render the tiles, the opengl code is not useful on Android. However, probably it's a good idea to not work on removing it from the Android binary till it's not clear if those opengl #ifdefs will go away or not in the long run. (Currently we have those ifdefs, but it's possible they will be reverted, it's not clear yet.)
AbandonedThanks, then it's safe to abandon this.

Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1Marking CommandInfoProvider members as static doesn't serve the purpose of this refactoring. What we want ideally is to kill CommandInfoProvider and FrameListener, and instead introduce a set of helper functions that do the same thing - provide an easy way to get command titles/images etc. There is no need to keep yet another static data for this.Also, I'm not sure how the current patch is supposed to work, given that the frame reference always stays nullptr?

Patch Set 1:It seems to me that this patch is trying to do something else than what is meant in tdf#45789.Your code does something when saving the report definition. At the time of saving the report definition, it is not possible to know what data will go in there (only at report *execution* time), so I don't see how your code can do the right thing for tdf#45789, whose purpose is to set the row height to what is needed FOR THE DATA FILLED IN.Conceptually, the work is "simpler" as far as the report execution engine is concerned; it just needs to set the "this row needs to have automatic height" bit on the table row(s) in the odt output and *writer* will compute the correct row height. No need of computation of row heights in report builder.On the other hand, it requires some work in the Report Builder UI to add a user-settable property there in order to allow the user to choose whether the row should, or should not, have automatic height.

Patch Set 1:Sorry about the spam guys. If you can't tell, I'm new here :) Why am I getting this conflict? I resubmitted my changes after I added some more changes, and I abandoned my previous attempts.

Patch Set 3:> Did you test this in your local environment ? build fails on all > platforms.I tried to test on Windows but after 2.5 hours of building it gave failing test due to OpenCL, which I know wasn't due to the patch, so I submitted it before actually testing it. I came to know via opengrok.libreoffice.org that there are more files that would need modification so I'm working on it.

Patch Set 2:> When I look at the file in master, it is very different from the > "base" in this patch, so you are building on something that is not > master. It is impossible to review code when we cannot see the > difference to master. >  > The file in master does not contain noexcept (I do not know why it > is in your code). >  > You need to work on an updated master (that builds without > problems) and then apply your patch there. That way we can see what > you change compared to master."noexcept" was added by me to determine the function which was causing crash, i forgot to remove before submitting.I will now update master and submit a new patch.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2(2 comments)So I think you are still not really understanding what you are doing.The typenames are horrible. Why create typedefs when you are never using them. Const and non-const member functions are completely random and don't even conform to the ones that are available in std::vector.Please learn a bit more C++ before working on LibreOffice. This is normally a trivial easy hack and should be easy to solve if you have a decent understanding of C++. Having this decent knowledge is required for most if not all LibreOffice C++ tasks.

Patch Set 4:sc/source/core/data/column.cxxLine 1134 => FixedLine 1140 => Fixedsc/source/core/data/column3.cxxLine 1595I would prefer to keep the modification for the following reasons. std::each is really slower than the code i propose. According to valgrind it saves a lot of events. I also made some profiling (summing the execution time of the call to this code for a full execution of SubTotal) on the two versions of the methods with the tests files i added (200 lines, 2000 then 20000) and i have the following results :200 lines std::each is 7,92% slower2000 lines std::each is 4,73% slower20000 lines std::each is 12,18% slowerCould you please give me more information on the problem it creates ? Is the StartListenersHandler declared the wrong way ? Line 2622 => FixedI reverted to the original code. You are right, the code is doing the same, and is not related to the formula performance.

Patch Set 1:HiThanks for the review. I'am sorry for the late answer. Many things to do, and it got out of my mind :( > Can we somehow make sure that it *always* gets set if a formula cell is present?I have patched all the methods in which Formula Cells are created. By defaultn the Sheet is initialized in a state meaning "It contains Formulas". It will be cleared after first check.  But maybe there is still a risk this happens. sc/inc/column.hxx 	Line 672 	=> fixedsc/source/core/data/column.cxx	Line 1136	=> fixed ( removed the call to setMayHaveFormula(true) )		Line 1144	=> fixed ( removed the call to setMayHaveFormula(true) )	Line 2395	> Instead of sprinkling this over various places, it could be added above to the place where IsEmptyData() is already checked and bail out early, or not?	Unfortunatly it is not possible to do so. Depending on the result of the test some needs to be executed or not, but it has to be in the given order. I don't see how to be the test in a single place. sc/source/core/data/column3.cxx	Line 1593	=> fixed	Line 1607	> Instead of allocating/deallocating a StartListenersHandler on the heap I'd rather let the one existing StartListenersHandler on the stack handle the flag as well by adding an ScColumn& member, which also was better readable code.	Code might be more readable, but the issue i have seen with the current handler is the std::for_each generate a call for each cell, even if they are not formulas. By doing it this way i can save really a lot of function calls. This has a real impact on performances when dealing with very large sheets (i am using one with 100 col x 100,000 rows).sc/source/core/data/column4.cxx	Line 536	=> Fixedsc/source/core/data/documentimport.cxx	Line 340	=> fixed	Line 361	=> fixed	Line 452	=> fixedsc/source/core/data/table1.cxx	Line 1498	=> Fixed 		I removed the check from the table object. You are right this is cleaner, but it could have saved a lot of function call :)sc/source/core/data/table2.cxx	Line 282		This has to be seen as "safe mode". By doing this i force to recheck each column for formulas. This is not optimal. But since i was not hundred 100% of with column to recheck it is safer. Help would be appreciated on this point (to identify which column to flag). Setting the falg when it is not necessary is not a problem at all. It will only fall back to current behavior, and flag will be cleared at next iteration.	Line 362		Same explanationsc/source/core/data/table7.cxx	Line 208 	=> Fixed ( test has been moved to ScColumn methods )

Patch Set 5:I'm not sure how you get your numbers. Maybe you are not using a release build.In a release build using the 200 row test case the ScColumn::StartListeners method is responsible for about 7% of the whole calculation time. Nearly none of that is related to std::for_each and nearly everything is related to the expensive calls in that method.

Patch Set 5:Hi KoheiYou were right my builds were not clean and i had some debug code. Sorry for that. I did a full rebuild of the libreoffice project with ./autogen.sh --without-java --without-help --without-myspell-dicts no more --enable-dbgutil  and i hope it is sufficient for enabling optimizations. I made more tests, and the code is still slightly faster (1 to 2%), but i think it is in the error tolerance, and anyways things are really more important than percent... i was talking about saving three seconds over a ten minutes computation. Not really worth it ;)So i will revert to the original code and the functor.Now my question is, do you you have a prefered way to send information between ScColumn::StartListeners and class StartListenersHandler ?My first idea is to add an extra parameters to the constructor, a reference to the column, so it could set the FomulaFlag? How about this ?

Patch Set 5:@EikeI fully understand that if the gain is not sufficient, stability prevails. Honestly i am no longer sure if my builds were debug or not... The information i posted were misleading because i switched to debug when i created the performance unit test. I do not remember my september builds.I am currently running a performance test with today's version and release build (./autogen.sh --without-java --without-help --without-myspell-dicts) using the different test case i used, and my original test file. So far the execution ratio is about 1.43 with the 2,000 lines file and about 1,35 with the 5,000 lines file.The performance test with the original file will take hours... so i propose to wait until tomorrow, then i will post more results and tests case you need. So far i have processed about 17% and the current line ratio is about x2. It is a current value, not an average. Average on the first 17% is close to 1.45 but should raise.

Patch Set 2:sc/source/core/data/column3.cxxLine 1562: Is there a reason why you rename it?   => FixedLine 1591: This variable should be defined after the return;=> FixedLine 1607: Should be acceptable now ? Line 1611: I would not dynamically allocate the handler. Instead I would allocate it on the stack.=> FixedLine 1791: If I'm not wrong there is just one case that will result in a formula cell. Why not handle this there?=> FixedLine 2632: Why did you remove the std::for_each with the functor?I have created a performance test case and added a few tests document i use for very large sheet. Tunning it on a 200 lines sheets shows that the number of collected events decrease by 22% (34.19bn with std::each and 'only' 27.95bn with my code). Thus it seems that the std::each is not optimized, and the functor is called for each cell. Check for a boolean is way faster. the operator is called only for cells containing formulas.sc/source/core/data/documentimport.cxxLine 339: This can be moved out of the loop.=> FixedLine 360: This can be moved out of the loop.=> FixedIt remains two questions i'll answer in my next comments, to which i'll attach the new patchset

Patch Set 4:Some functions seems in need to handle both. I guess we can't change the VBA interface ;-)Now there is INetURLObject(OUString const & rFSysPath, FSysStyle eStyle), so probably we can get rid of osl::FileBase::getFileURLFromSystemPath, if we set eStyle according to the system settings?I also missed the smart parsing functionality. I had a look now, but didn't find code which would just accept system specific local paths, as there seems to be no system setting for FSYS_*, as FSYS_DETECT will - as far as my fast gimplse at the code told me - happily accept file URLs in any system notation, if you pass FSYS_DETECT.And there are a lot more users of osl::FileBase::getFileURLFromSystemPath, which expect a local path right from the start. Some expect to use the input path, if it's correct, while others want the GetMainURL(). But I just found one with a different decoding then NO_DECODE.I can convert everything to smart URL and run make check, but I can't verify all places. We just need to define a FSYS_SYSTEM value somewhere, so we won't accept other system file encodings.

Patch Set 1:Yeah, finally groked now what's going on.  GCC 6 libstdc++'s (override of the system) <math.h> now has a "using std::abs" in the global namespace, so that libstdc++ std::abs(integral)->double template in <cmath> (to cater for C++11's---arguably broken, see <http://cplusplus.github.io/LWG/lwg-active.html#2192> "Validity and return type of std::abs(0u) is unclear"---requirements) started to become visible here.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1Basically not a bad approach, but it should be done more modular, e.g. create a primitive class hich has gradient stops and decomposes to the already existing FillGradientPrimitive2D, so nothing has to change there (safe) and the new classes will extend the functionality in the sende of primitives (as intended). This would also avoid the from my POV unacceptable double definition of StartColor/EndColor.In general it can be done to extend all 'classic' gradients to gradient stops (modular), but is questionable - evtl. implementing the SVG gradient definitions and using these if needed would be superiour. This can also be done using primitives and a decomposition, so all renderers would be capable of crunching these.
