Patch Set 1:(1 comment)> (1 comment) >  > note that fixing external/neon/ leaves --with-system-neon (incl. > indirectly via --with-system-libs) configurations brokenI see.The real issue here is why the URL sent to webdav_ucp::Content ctor is not always the same, some time it's like:(1)  https://192.168.1.80:8443/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem%20'%20ipsum.odtand some other time it's like:(2)  https://192.168.1.80:8443/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem%20%27%20ipsum.odtboth starting from the human readable resource unescaped URL:https://192.168.1.80:8443/alfresco/webdav/Sites/davtest/documentLibrary/Lorem ' ipsum.odtIMHO that's the main reason.I think (2) should be the right one, according to this:<https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3986#section-2.2>where the apostrophe is considered a reserved character.So, to avoid this neon patch, the only other way is have LO escape a document URL always in the same way.

Patch Set 1:Hmm, is this only a nice-to-have patch or it makes life really hard on the g-d side if this is not accepted?I'm asking as up to today, we could freely add as many new signals as we wanted to the widget without breaking ABI. However, with your patch, the list of signals become part of the ABI and we limit the number of new signals ever to be added.In other words it's a large cost to support these function pointers -- if possible, it would be really nice to avoid this. The larger the interface we promise to be stable, the harder to make future changes.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1This patch obviously does not what is mentioned in the commit message.The second question is what is the use-case of adding the line to a test declaration. I understand the advantage of having a line in an assert macro as there might be several in one test case but for the the CPPUNIT_TEST_FAIL this would mean that you just get a pointer to the declaration. You get the sme with a quick git grep or even opening the source file and looking at the declaration of the tests.It would be the same as printing the source line of the test declaration in a CPPUNIT_TEST macro instead of the source line of the assert that failed.

Patch Set 1:> This patch obviously does not what is mentioned in the commit message.Well it adds the source position of the test declaration.I don't understand why you think the commit message is wrong?> The second question is what is the use-case of adding the line to a> test declaration. I understand the advantage of having a line in an> assert macro as there might be several in one test case but for> the CPPUNIT_TEST_FAIL this would mean that you just get a pointer to> the declaration. You get the same with a quick git grep or even> opening the source file and looking at the declaration of the tests.Since the test fails, if it passes, there is nothing else to point to, except for the declaration, where the test is declared as "fail if pass".For CPPUNIT_TEST you can obviously point to the failling assertion, which isn't possible in the non-failing fail case.I'm not going to fight for it. I'm myself not sure, if it makes much sense, as it probably would make more sense to point to the implementation, but that's impossible.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2QtCreator creates those files when it refuses to load the .pro.user files. So nothing useful there. (.pro.user files aren't useful in this case either, but that's another issue.)

Patch Set 2:> That's strange, then do you happen to know why QtCreator 3.4 would > refuse to import the .pro.user files 'make qtcreator-ide-integration' > generated? > Does the integreation only work with older QtCreator versions?Not sure. I read in several places in the net that .pro.user files are tied to a specific environment, so it might be that it doesn't work even with older versions (and that there is .pro.shared file that can be used in such cases, to some extent). I plan to experiment with different Qt Creator version when I'll have some free time, and I'll update here if I'll find something useful.

Patch Set 2:OK, here is what I found:Loading .pro.user files doesn't work even in earlier versions. To make Qt Creator load the .pro.user file, you must go to ~/.config/QtProject/qtcreator/profiles.xml and copy the profile ID from there to the "ProjectExplorer.ProjectConfiguration.Id" key in the .pro.user file. This situation is unfortunate, but that's what we have right now.(Note that Qt creator will still create the .pro.user.3.2-pre1 file, but it's just a backup of the old file, and is not actually used, so it can be removed safely.)

Patch Set 4:*I uploaded the 4th patch because when you give me -1 on patch 3 there are an error in my code I checked it and fixed it.*This bug is a simple hack which I found it in the simple hacks list " https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/Easy_Hacks/lists/by_Difficulty#Easy_Hacks_for_Beginners " Bug 89756*Here is someone also solved the same bug but she didn't fix all files which are mentioned in the Bug, so I fixed the rest " https://gerrit.libreoffice.org/#/c/14903/ "*Generally prefix bit better than postfix beacuse the compiler, upon seeing i++, creates a temporary object to hold the original value of i so that after the increment completes the original value of i can be returned.  A temporary is not required when compiling ++i since the value returned by the increment operation is the value i has after the increment has completed.  This means that i++ requires more memory and runs more slowly than ++i

Patch Set 4:We certainly don't want to sacrifice readability for imagined speed benefits not proved by profiling. Premature optimisation is evil. Prefix increment or decrement is OK for simple variables, and especially in for loops, where using it is kinda an idiom. But something like --aCrsrSt.m_pCrsr->GetMark()->nContentis horrible.I hope I am not alone having this opinion...

Patch Set 2:That's a pretty important "only"... does the add-in GCD function match Excel's?

Patch Set 2:@tml:Yes, The GCD() function is Calc matches the Excel function, with two notes:-Excel has limits for the size of the arguments (must be less than 2E53), Calc doesn't and never had that limit (neither Calc's own, nor add-in function);-Excel GCD accepts only integer arguments in Excel versions prior to 2007 and accepts floating point arguments since Excel 2007, Calc accepts all numeric arguments (both Calc's own as add-in function).It is quite common for Calc functions to be more tolerant with respect to type and/or numeric value limits than their Excel counterparts.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So, as-is this compiles ... and crashes/asserts for now -- at least with a debug build.There have been some attempts to use unique_ptrs or scoped_ptrs on SwUnoCrsr -- however, as these are kept as naked pointer in SwUnoCrsrTbl too, which mindlessly deletes everything it still finds around on ~SwDoc, the ownership of these is a terrible mess.I'd suggest to use the blunt device of a shared_ptr as a starting point (and a weak_ptr in SwUnoCrsrTbl) to get somewhat sensible ownership of these in the mid-term.In the long run, the users of the SwUnoCrsrTbl should likely be listeners to all the SwUnoCrsrs (registered right in CreateUnoCrsr) and thus removing the need for having a SwUnoCrsrTbl in the first place. But that is still way off.So, as an intermediate step: using shared_ptrs.@mst, caolan: opinions? is this worth finalizing this?

Patch Set 6:I still don't like introducing a new document-wide UNO setting when we already have a setting in ODF format doing exactly the same ...Anyway, I did some git archaeology and found out that this "Impress always opens on 1st slide" is an artificial restriction imposed by a design document + OOo feature request from 2005 (https://bz.apache.org/ooo/show_bug.cgi?id=50902)Moreover, keyboard accelerator listed therein (Shift-F5) that was supposed to be used to jump to the last edited slide (the one saved as SelectedPage) no longer works, since it is used for different purpose now (start a slideshow from current slide)So I think this restriction (always open on 1st slide, unless the presentation is an embedded OLE object) can nowadays be removed and that should be the way to fix this issue. I.e. removing this 'if ...( SFX_CREATE_MODE_EMBEDDED == pDoc->GetDocSh()->GetCreateMode()' condition when reading SelectedPage setting ... unless it crashes Impress or cause other nasties ...Anyway, I'm adding Thorsten to Cc: to get a second opinion on that ...

Patch Set 5:The changes are being saved to the odp file when the file is saved because AFAIK,  UNO document settings are written again when we save the document.In settings.xml of the odp file:You can find<config:config-item config:name="CurrentPage" config:type="short">2</config:config-item>And if you modify document again and save at some other slide then, it would be modified:<config:config-item config:name="CurrentPage" config:type="short">4</config:config-item>Also the code in frmview.cxx  loads the current page while loading the document. (pDrawDoc->GetCurrentPage() )Can you please cherry-pick and try. I don't think we need that import and export code as mentioned in comment 3 on the bug page.Thanks for the letting me know about the variable naming, will fix that.

Patch Set 1:Hi, Rishabh: congratulations and thanks a lot for sending your first patch to LibreOffice! We appreciate it.I have a few recommendations for your commit message:1. When reading a git log, it is useful to have a few details on the rationale behind a change: what problem are you solving, what approach youÔÇÖve followed to fix it, etc. Examples of good commit messages are in PoeditÔÇÖs repo, this is a random example: https://github.com/vslavik/poedit/commit/d6af8b16f386c92af4ad3107346990a57d92d4c5(Of course, you donÔÇÖt have to write novels out of commit messages, but most of the time a few explaining sentences are prefectly fine.)2. We have just (like a few days ago!) migrated to our own instance of Bugzilla (we used FreeDesktop.orgÔÇÖs one before), so thw way we refer to bugs has changed: instead of using the abbreviation ÔÇ£fdo#ÔÇØ we now use ÔÇ£tdf#ÔÇØ.Thanks again your your submission!

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1Looks lovely to me - but - I'm a tad concerned; in terms of making this a pure re-factor I think we need to ensure that widgets are destroyed at the same time as they were ...void IIIMPStatusWindow::dispose()+{+    m_aStatusBtn.clear();So - all of these type of dispose impls should be:if (m_aStatus.get()) m_aStatus.dispose(); m_aStatusBtn.clear();-except- that we really ought to have a helper method here to avoid recursion so:void doDispose(Reference<Foo> &rRef){     Reference<Foo> aTmp(rRef);     rRef.clear(); // we should use some 'swap' method ideally ;-)     rRef.dispose();    // unref as goes out of scope}And of course - we really need to move the body of ~Window into Window::dispose - (like almost all of it - and guard it against double disposes too ;)With those two in place this starts to look really sexy.Many thanks !

Patch Set 1:> my concern is not for the Chinese users, but rather for English UI.This issue is not present in English-language environments because the Segoe UI font is used there. This is actually a Windows issue, because it is not falling back to Segoe UI when starting a program in English when your UI font is YaHei, JhengHei or Meiryo.> Maybe I should file a bug report on bugzilla and let someone else test and confirm?Sadly we have no control over such font issues. Microsoft owns a kind of bug tracker called Microsoft Connect, perhaps they already know about this. Also, they usually update the UI fonts when a new Windows version comes out. It would be interesting to try to reproduce the issue in Windows 8.1 or 10.

Patch Set 5:Hi Miklos,- I have been looking into the issue for visual disparity.- In order to understand the root cause of the visual disparity, studied what is missing/added to the XML which is leading to the visual disparity.- Compared the round trip file on master with the original file.- It is observed that the round trip file on master and the original file is not the same. The order of exporting the text and the table is different even on master.- Next, compared the round trip file  on my fix and the round trip file on master.- The sequence of writing the text and the table is same in these round trip files[master RT and fix RT].- Thus there is no regression added due to this fix.- Next, studied the styles.xml [master round trip vs fix round trip], it is observed that there is absolutely no difference.- Request you to have look on the screen shot --- http://wikisend.com/download/730630/OriginalMasterFix.png- I discussed with the DEV team here, as per our understanding, we can go ahead to with this patch as there is no technical difference between master and the Fix RT.- There is no critical issue like data loss and the main issue is with the corruption which has been resolved.- Let me know If I can re-base the patch with latest master and we can go ahead to merge this issue to master. Thanks :)

Patch Set 5:> Thus there is no regression added due to this fix.Sorry, this is not what I see. http://people.freedesktop.org/~vmiklos/2014/gerrit9914/2014-08-01/ clearly shows the regression this patch would introduce. Fixing a bug by introducing an other is not ideal. :-)I know, it sometimes happens, but the purpose of code review is to try to detect such problems *before* the patch goes in. This is exactly that situation, so I hope you understand that you can't expect me to approve this patch as-is. Please improve the patch to not break the visual layout of the existing test document, then I'm happy to approve the patch.Thanks! :-)

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1So, Markus and I had the same discussion years ago.  The reason why we still keep auto_ptr there was 2 things: 1) make the code exception safe, and 2) ptr_set requires auto_ptr to be passed to be truly exception safe.  2) is a loose requirement and you can also pass a raw pointer to ptr_set (as you noticed).  But your current change is a step backward in terms of 1).The best strategy for this use case is to use o3tl::heap_ptr to replace auto_ptr, and call heap_ptr's release() when passing it to ptr_set.  Then the code remains exception safe and we can get rid of auto_ptr.

Patch Set 1:No, files generated by MS Office 2010 does not  contain ';' instead they contain ':' , but user can  change the hyperlink address.If the hyperlink contains ';', MS Office 2010 is not able to open that link.i.e the hyperlink gets broken.however, MS Office is able to open .docx.But without my changes, I get an error dialog which tells that roundtrip file is corrupted & MS Office 2010 is not able to open that document.So, in order to get rid of this corruption & successfully open the roundtrip docx in MS Office 2010 this change has been proposed.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I see.The root problem on the LO side is that INetURLObject eagerly normalizes URLs, so something passed in as <file:///c;/...> gets passed out again as <file:///c%3B/...>.  Fixing this is quite a task, but eventually should be addressed.The problem with the proposed patch is that while it fixes this single problem, it may break others.  That aMustEncodeMap is used centrally in INetURLObject for all the different URI schemas, and ";" does have syntactical significance within path segments in general (e.g., in ftp URLs).  Also, would the odd behavior of MS Office 2010 be restricted to ";" vs. "%3B", or are there further characters that would need "fixing?"Also, how severe is this problem in practice?  What is the user's intent in making the URL dysfunctional by replacing ":" with ";"---is it about the user inadvertently introducing a typo?In short, I see no better fix than eventually tackling the root problem as described above.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2Actually this is not exactly a duplicate.Calc has 2 separate "paste special" dialogs. One is when pasting from system clipboard, and the other is pasting from Calc itself.  This one you are proposing to change is used for the 2nd variant.Try opening a new Calc document, and while nothing is copied, hit Ctrl-Shift-V.  This will bring up the system paste special dialog.  Now, select some cells and Ctrl-C to copy, then Ctrl-Shift-V. This will bring up the Calc paste special dialog.I'm not saying we shouldn't change this wording, but I'm not in favor of calling this "insert contents" which would make less sense than "paste special".

Patch Set 4:I think that this change isn't worth it because it mostly just adds churn to Git, makes it harder to integrate code from AOO, etc. There is plenty of precedent for functions that Enable() stuff to take a boolean parameter to disable. Anyone qualified enough to write C++ in LO won't find that function a real stumbling block. I think these sorts of mechanical changes should have a goal in mind, like moving towards a new string class or something. But just going around renaming every suboptimal function in the product could take years and still not really improve or simplify the product in the ways LibreOffice greatly needs.

Patch Set 2:The tests are not the right place to improve our python examples. Tests have to be maintained and should be as close to the tested code as possible. Obviously putting two additional layers between your test code and the tested code won't help in this case.I'm always happy to see more tests and despite my reluctance to more Python tests I can accept them for API tests but I'm not happy with them if we use them to test internal calc code through UNO. Actually I would be unhappy with the test as well if it would be written in C++ and use UNO to test against this problem.

AbandonedI'm going to pull this... I've misunderstood how the SalGraphics interface is working. GetGraphics returns a NULL if the graphics instance is being used, it pulls back the graphics instance if it released and blocks it from reuse, otherwise if there is NO graphics device at all (either released or blocked) then it creates the graphics device and then returns the newly created graphics.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1I am afraid this is not exactly what we should be doing here.  The DataChanged() is a kind of fallback in case we were subclassing Application; so that the subclass can implement its own DataChanged() and react accordingly.  [In general, please be careful when changing signature of a virtual function, as when it changes in a superclass, but not in the subclasses, it usually leads to situations that the code in subclasses is not called any more.]The VCLEVENT_APPLICATION_DATACHANGED broadcast is kind of unrelated here, it is broadcasting to the others, does not affect the application itself.I am tempted to abandon your change, sorry for that :-( - unless you think nobody is actually using or going to use the Application's DataChanged(), and in that case we should just remove it from Application for good?
AbandonedThat's a fair call :-) My understanding was limited.

AbandonedI am sorry, but prefer not to do this :-)  The caller of PostUserEvent is notified when the call hasn't succeeed, because in that case the PostUserEvent returns 0, so it is responsibility of the caller to judge if it was an error situation, or not - too much SAL_WARN's in not-so-much-error cases can lead to programmers actually ignoring what it is trying to tell them :-)
AbandonedRight, so -- please submit this again when you have a better version, it makes no sense to have this at this stage in the review queue. Thanks! :-)

AbandonedAbandoning this one, pending for 5 months, referred other change that should be combined into this is already abandoned. Please submit a new change if the mentioned problems are corrected. Thanks! :-)

Patch Set 1:Looking good - to readd it to this change, you need to run:git rebase -iThis will take you into your favourite text editor. Take the latter change (the last line) and where it says "pick" change this to "s". This "squashes" the commit into the previous commit. Save and exit the editor. At this point, you might be taken into another editor session, remove all the comments (and Gerrit changeset ID) from the commit you just squashed. Then save and exit again. It should rebase the changes into the first commit with the first commit message. Then push the change to gerrit again as you did last time.

Patch Set 1:> Please try to provide atomic changes instead of all-in-one commit.I can try to split it up, but of course only if there is a chance to get the changes in (honestly: without major changes in the way BT is handled, I'd not recommend the remote to anyone)> in such case this dialog should be shown on *every* launch No, only when BT wasn't enabled already. And how often do you launch the Remote, how often do you give a talk? Once a day? Once a Week? Once a Month or even just one year at a conference?> which is *extremely* annoying.I started and used the remote for testing quite a bit, and I think hitting OK is neither extremely annoying, nor very timeconsuming.> The concept of ÔÇ£work and auto-do things without touching any buttons or dialogsÔÇØ is a lot better for everyone./That/ was a good one. The current remote* doesn't list bonded devices, I have to set the computer to be visible just to use the remote.ÔåÆ this involves more steps and clicks than just hitting "OK" directly after launching the remote (only if BT wasn't already enabled.* frequently enough kills my BT, so I have to reboot the phone to be able to turn on bluetooth again. Now /that/ is annoying.> BluetoothOperator is a layer of abstraction. For example, on Jelly Bean the BluetoothAdapter instance should be acquired the other way if you read the comment.That is only a concern once the API is completely removed and a check is needed. Until then, no problem to get rid offunciton do_stuff { return do_this(); }function do_this { reutrn call_something_else(); }function call_something_else { return A != B }> Another layer of abstraction actually helps readability this way.Having to traverse multiple files and even then multiple one-line-functions to track back a simple boolean comparison doesn't help readability at all. I find it highly annoying and irritating, like artificially obscuring what the code does by hiding it under a long chain of function calls.functions that are only called by one single other method, with no chances of being reused.You mention that aquiring the bt adapter might require version checks, but honestly: Before you use different api by checking the runtime version, you rather keep using the deprecated version that works flawlessly. > I cannot review other things because the commit is really huge.It just looks large, the changes themselves are small.> Can you consider opening an issue on Bugzilla first we discuss your problems with Bluetooth first and then fixing them instead of ÔÇ£recode everythingÔÇØ?The problems are:* not showing known (bonded) devices, forcing the user to make the computer visible* forcing a discovery on every start, on every use, that is useless for most users, as they usually use the same devices. So they are known, and after initial pairing set to   hidden, so even the search would not show result.* even doing the recovery in an endless loop* killing the BT connection when rotating the screenProbably the last one in combination with the automatically started discovery is what puts my BT adapter in a non-working state where I cannot enable it anymore and have to reboot the device.

Patch Set 1:This patch contains a possible way to load English or local add-in function names, depending on the global setting 'use English function names'. I wonder if this is the right way to do that. Currently, changing the global settings only is effected after a restart of LibreOffice; I haven't found a neat way yet to do this inmediately.The class ScUnoAddInFuncData has members aUpperName and aUpperLocal. It would seem to be logical to use these members, making a switch between local and English function names easy and efficient, but the 'normal' function list isn't used this way either. Why is this, or am I wrong?Some other lines in the code may possibly be removed, I would like some expert's opinion on this (see comments in the code).Any hints/suggestions on this subject is welcome :)(I will probably not be able to respond till 16 September or so, please don't be offended if I don't respond sooner.)

Patch Set 1:Uhm, so yes, seeing the patch and reading the bug, I indeed didn't realize that the intent is the opposite. However, are we sure this would be a worthy effort?My understanding is that typically a random source file in $srcdir/$module/source/sub/foo.cxx has -I for:- $srcdir/include- $module/inc- (sometimes) $module/source/sub/incIf getting rid of the second is the target, and the benefit is one less compile switch at a cost of modifying tons of source files -- is that really good?

Patch Set 1:This needs to be tested with buildbot.I made this patch with this bash script:#!/bin/bashfor k in `find $1/source -type f \( -name "*.cxx" -o -name "*.h" \) -print`do        echo 'File ' $k        for i in `grep "#include" $k`        do                  > ret                 if [ "$i" == "#include" ]; then                        continue                fi                  echo "Testing $i"                make $1.clean 1>/dev/null                sed "s|#include $i|\/\/test#include $i|g" "$k" > "$k".alter                rm $k                mv $k.alter $k                make $1 2> ret 1>/dev/null                if cat ret | grep -w 'error' 2>/dev/null 1>/dev/null                then                        sed "s|\/\/test#include $i|#include $i|g" "$k" > "$k".alter                        rm $k                        mv $k.alter $k                fi          donedoneSo, this script do a "make clean", comments a include, do a make, and if this throws an error, this script uncomment that include.So, this script helps us to find useless includes.Maybe the buildbot could find some mistakes, but this build nicely in Linux.

Patch Set 8:how do one end up with CR in autogen.input ?that seems to indicate very bad editor setting, andyou should fail on autogen.input rather than risk polluting the rest of the code no?

Patch Set 8:> how do one end up with CR in autogen.input ? that seems to indicate very bad editor setting,Text editors on Windows use CRLF for line endings as default settings when they create new file. I think it isn't bad editor setting. I encountered fdo#66885 when I create new autogen.input file.Of cause when we open existing file, almost editors including I used adapts the existing file's line endings so it hardly occurs that writing CR on text file with LF.> ... and you should fail on autogen.input rather than risk polluting the rest of the code no?I think no. Because detecting polluted text files is the job of git's hook script or code review. It's not the job of autogen.input. Plus, git's hook script and code reviewing can't check autogen.input's line endings effectively. Therefore permitting CRLF for autogen.input is the best solution for fdo#66885.

Patch Set 2: This need some tweaks before it is mergedsorry for taking so long to look at this, had something urgent to do last week and then forgot about it :(trying to fix a redlining bug... that's very ambitious :)from just trying it out it doesn't appear to work fully yet; with the steps from the bug description it appears to be even worse than before: the second paragraph gets reformatted to the style of the first (fully deleted) one when creating the redline, which did not happen before.this is also not reverted when Undo is applied...on Redo i get an assert from ~SwIndexReg but that is totally not your fault, happens without your bug too (note to self: investigate that).some obvious problems with the approach:- AppendRedline() is not really prepared to do changes that would require Undo- AppendRedline() may call itself recursively in case there are already existing redlines at that position; probably we would only want to modify styles for an actual newly inserted redline, not for something that has been inserted previously (since in that case the adjustment has already been done?)- the newly inserted redline can be split up too, do we want this to be done twice then?perhaps it would be better to do this in the caller of AppendRedline, when a new DELETE redline is created?hmm... the various RecurseThroughLinkedRedline calls don't appear to do anything with Undo either...of course this being redlining there are many non-obvious problems that i haven't thought of yet :)anyway this needs to be fully revert-able on Undo before it goes in.

Patch Set 2:>This need some tweaks before it is mergedOK> sorry for taking so long to look at this, had something urgent to do last week and then forgot about it :(Don't worry> trying to fix a redlining bug... that's very ambitious :)IndeedÔÇª it takes me some time to figure out what was going wrong and how to solve it.> from just trying it out it doesn't appear to work fully yet; with the steps from the bug description it appears to be even worse than before: the second paragraph gets reformatted to the style of the first (fully deleted) one when creating the redline, which did not happen before.It was done one purpose, it's the behaviour I want.When you activate the redlining (Edit ÔåÆ Changes ÔåÆ Record) without showing the changes ("Edit ÔåÆ Changes ÔåÆ Show" disabled) and you delete a paragraph the next one gets reformatted. Why should it be different when the changes are shown.When the modification showing is disabled the paragraphs linked by "deletion redline" became one and so are formatted with the same attributes. It should be the same when the modification showing is enable (else it became confusing for the user) so the patch makes sure all the formats (direct and named) applied to one paragraph are applied to the paragraphs linked with it by deletion redlines.> this is also not reverted when Undo is applied...I know, I put a TODO line in SwDoc::AppendRedline.I will try to handle UndoÔÇª> AppendRedline() may call itself recursively in case there are already existing redlines at that position; probably we would only want to modify styles for an actual newly inserted redline, not for something that has been inserted previously (since in that case the adjustment has already been done?)What makes you believe AppendRedline can be called recursively?> the newly inserted redline can be split up too, do we want this to be done twice then?I don't get itÔÇª> hmm... the various RecurseThroughLinkedRedline calls don't appear to do anything with Undo either...Indeed, I didn't bother about Undo when I was writing the patch (redlining was difficult enough). I will try to adapt it.> anyway this needs to be fully revert-able on Undo before it goes in.Understood

Patch Set 1: (4 inline comments)1) IMHO the negative year fix should go in independently of the time zone issue.3) Why should DateTimeRange contain only one time zone, as opposed to one for   the start value and one for the end value?3) You add time zone information to dates. I don't know the meaning of that.   What would it mean, how would it behave, what would it be used for?   For example, naively, one would think that combining a date with a time,   one would get a datetime. How does one get a datetime by combining   2003-05-17+05 with 23:00-06?   FWIW, SQL does not define a DATE WITH TIME ZONE type.4) I have my doubts about time-zoned time without a date.   How do you convert 20:00+00 to time zone +10?   Just "wrap around" modulo 24, i.e. make it 06:00+10?   If you answer yes to that question (that is, always compute modulo 24),   then what is the difference between 06:00+11 and 06:00-13?   The difference only makes sense if one speaks of dates...   Which says that timezones don't make sense unless we know at what date   to apply them.   FWIW, SQL defines a TIME WITH TIME ZONE TYPE, *but* here's what   the PostgreSQL documentation has to say about it:   The type time with time zone is defined by the SQL standard, but the definition exhibits properties which lead to questionable usefulness. In most cases, a combination of date, time, timestamp without time zone, and timestamp with time zone should provide a complete range of date/time functionality required by any application.   (...) we recommend using date/time types that contain both date and time when using time zones. We do not recommend using the type time with time zone (though it is supported by PostgreSQL for legacy applications and for compliance with the SQL standard).I have half a mind to add timezone *only* to DateTime and DateTimeRange,not to Date and not to Time. Note that this would more-or-less eliminateall conversion problems, and "unlock" the scenario "don't add timezoneto structs, but convert everything to UTC", since conversion of datetimevalues across timezones is AFAIK well-defined. "Convert everything to UTC"is SQL's behaviour; in SQL all non-timezoned values are assumed to be atlocal time and a date is converted to the timestamp "same date at time 00:00".Alternative approach to your "isTimezoned": have a separate struct "DateTimeTZ"?Your "isTimezoned" flag should IMHO be called "isUTC".Do we actually *need* *any* "unknown timezone / local timezone" value in memory?We could just make some assumption (UTC or local TZ) on import/parse/readand store only UTC in memory. Oh, but it would be convenient for our APIs to havethe capacity to take implicitly-localTZ values, yes.If we go the "assume that values without explicit time zone are in local time" route,then that flag should be called "isUTC".So, I've spoken of what SQL does as a reference;https://wiki.documentfoundation.org/Development/LibreOffice4#Changes_deferred_until_4.1mentions XMLSchema-2. Let's see what it does for another reference: - It (optionally) timezones everything: date, time and datetime. - I don't see a datetimerange in it. - It understands a date as a 24-hour interval   (a DateTimeRange, from date 00:00:00.00000000 to 23:59:59.999999999 for most days,    that is except for leap seconds),    while SQL seems to consider it more like an instant, time 00:00 at that day. - A value without timezone is "unknown timezone" and not comparable   to a value with timezone, but on the other hand, section 3.2.7 also calls   untimezoned values "local values", which supports the idea that they are   "local time". But "local time" is unspecified in an interchange file format,   because the file may move from one timezone to the other.   In SQL, everything is convertible/comparable because each session has an   active "local timezone" which is used for all untimezoned values.Pragmatically, how close to XMLSchema-2 do we need to be?1) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a date with timezone?2) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a time (*not* datetime) with timezone?3) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where there can be a   datetime with timezone OR a datetime without timezone and the difference   has some semantic significance (other than "interpret value without   timezone in this timezone").4) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a datetime value without timezone and preserve unmodified as   without timezone?   The kind of scenario I'm thinking of is:   We read a datetime value without timezone from some file, and the file   does not give a context that tells us what time zone to interpret that in,   the user changes stuff, but not the part with that datetime value,   *and* when saving the file again, we need to write back the same value,   as opposed to say the UTC value of that datetime-in-local-timezone   or the same datetime value with local-timezone affixed.5) Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we need to import   or export a datetime value without timezone, do changes on it and preserve   it as without timezone?   The kind of scenario I'm thinking of is:   We read a datetime value without timezone from some file, and the file   does not give a context that tells us what time zone to interpret that in,   the user e.g. tells us "add one hour to that datetime value",   *and* when saving the file again, we need to write back the new value   as untimezoned, as opposed to say the UTC value of that   datetime-in-local-timezone or the same datetime value with local-timezone   affixed.

Patch Set 2:>>> Is there any part of ODF/OOXML/any other format where we>>> need to import or export a date with timezone?> >>> dunno about OOXML> > Then bring (one of) our resident expert(s) in this discussion.vmiklos says it's using XMLSchema-2 too> Here's what I would consider optimal:> >  - All our (date)time API calls take and return UTC (date)time or>    untimezoned (date)time. That is, our (date)time structure>    does not have a timezone in it. It is UTC or untimezoned.but this would mean that (to be able to preserve user-supplied time-zoneoffsets) everywhere you want to store a time-zoned value you need anadditional Property to store an explicit time-zone if it isn'tcontained in the value itself.>  - Hmm... As an alternative / complement to the above service,>    the (date)time struct constructors takes an optional argument>    that says "the values I'm giving are UTC / localtime / untimezoned">    (we add a new enum with these three values), and the constructor>    makes the appropriate localtime->UTC conversion.> >    Can we do that in UNO? I'm unsure. Actually, I don't expect so.not possible, struct constructors are auto-generated.> The spanner in the works, and the reason I'm torn, is timezoned dates.> They don't fit the above schema. I hate them. For timezoned dates,> we *have* to include an explicit timezone in the struct, or expect that> code will store timezoned dates as a pair of values (a date and an> offset) - bleh. This gives us an inconsistent interface between date> on one hand and (date)time on the other hand.yes.> So, the choice boils down to:> >  - inconsistent, but best for (date)time: use UTC for timezoned data.>    explicit timezone for timezoned date.> >  - consistent, but unnecessarily annoying for (date)time: add explicit>    timezone everywhere. Provide a UNO service that answers the>    question "is this the same point in time"? (that is, semantic equality)hmmm... having a service for that would probably be quite useful,it could also do other things like "convert to given time zone" or"combine this timezoned Date and Time properly".> Do we *really* *really* need timezoned dates, or are they a bug> in the ODF specification?if anything they're a bug in XMLSchema-2.but actually the definitions appear internally consistent to me.> Now, I turn to our internal use. IMHO, untimezoned values should just> be incomparable to timezoned values. Throw an error if it comes up.actually the un-timezoned ones can often be compared properly,except not if it's within 28 hours of a timezoned one.

Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)> In lcl_ConvertTimeZone() in sax/source/tools/converter.cxx, > you are attempting to convert times between timezones. > I don't think this can be done safely without access to a > DST (Daylight Savings Time) database. It depends what you call "timezone". If it is something like "Europe/Amsterdam", that is "the time in Amsterdam", then yes, DST matters. But here, the notion of timezone is just an offset from UTC. That is, we consider that Amsterdam *changes* timezone twice per year. In this case, sure, we can freely / safely convert, we just have to subtract the offset.

Patch Set 1:"then this really is simple"repeating it does not make it so...returning a const OUString& does mean that the guy the receive it cannot modify it... it does not mean that the owner of the reference cannot... and there is code that return a const String& of some internal variable, or a ref to the global empty string.it is not always that obvious that one can safely replace that ref by a value...beside if that was that obvious why did it get used to start with ?Anyway.. I've been pissing in the wind too long on that topic.. I'll do like everybody has done... create static OUString() as needed... oh well

Patch Set 1: Do not mergeWith the caveat that I presume the intent is not code 'cleaning', but doxygenification...two things:1/ random changing of // into //< or /// is not helping if that does not fit with how doxygen actually work... for instance, inside the implementation of a function I wonder what is intended2/ if you are going to tackle the very valuable goal of improving the doxygen documentation of a module, then stick to one and do it starting from the logical top (making sure the file/classes are documented)then work your way through the public header section, and eventually the private header section...Do not just randomly change a line or two here and there.. especially across completely unrelated source file.Note that this is much more work than it seems, since useful documentation require that you actually read and understand the class you are documenting... if it was as simple of a mechanical s@//@//<@ then we would have written a script to do so already.

Patch Set 1: Do not mergeSorry, no. The assert is there for a reason. It is *good* to use lots of assertions in the code. We certainly don't want to remove them. In a non-debug build that assert() expands to nothing, and thus to the compiler it seems that s is unused.So the correct fix is to either make the compiler ignore the unusedness of s by adding a   (void) s;   statement, or replace s with the expression that is assigned to it inside the assert().
Patch Set 1:I'd like some testing of this - and some review of it vs. master too of course :-) Thorsten would be ideal.

Patch Set 1:Is there a reason why you see the need for python unit tests? When evaluating the options for our unit testing frameworks we also evaluated the use of python to write our tests and decide against it for several reasons including the problems while debugging the tests.I'm a bit concerned with adding a new language for testing the c++ code. We have already the java test which go through the uno java bridge and it turned out to be a real pain to maintain these tests.Personally I prefer to keep tests in the same language as the code that should be tested to make it easier to maintain them.

Patch Set 2:Isn't this a bit like deciding the right language for implementing UNO services in core?There (as far as I understand) the opinion is that new code should use C++, but Java -> Python conversion is considered useful (think of converting wizards). Can't we apply the same rule here, saying that for new tests, C++ is preferred, but converting existing Java tests to Python is useful?Also, I wonder how hard would it be to run the Python tests in-process; IIRC there is already support for running "Python scripts", couldn't that be reused to avoid the remote UNO pain we have right now with Java tests?

Patch Set 2:'VRIF' is generic category, i. e. you can verify by a tinderbox, or you can verify manually.If you introduce new category: TNDB for Tinderbox, then both have to be positive: VRIF & TNDB.What Norbert come up with is to have the follow values for VRIF -2,-1,0,+1,+2And let gerrit buildbot verification only vote -1,+1,+2, so that the developer still can overwrite the failure (-1) with his +2, in case he thinks it was false negative.

Patch Set 2:My proposal was rather to have no 'verified' field as other gerrit installations use 'verified' in the sense it is used on e.g. bugzilla: 'I have run the application and can confirm the bug is gone with this.' -- which is not what our tinderboxes do (or can do).So using a field titled 'tinderbox' would be a bit more honest: a +1/+2 just means that, and a developers manually giving a +2 there is meaning just that: 'I tested the build or am reasonably confident that it doesnt break the build (but I have not tested the fix to remove the bug its claiming to fix)'.No blocking whatsoever from my side, just some thoughts.

Patch Set 1:m_xRootFolder = m_pRootFolder = new ZipPackageFolder( m_nFormat, m_bAllowRemoveOnInsert );where m_xRootFolder is ::com::sun::star::uno::Reference < com::sun::star::container::XNameContainer > m_xRootFolderlooks to me that we're not supposed to call delete directly on that m_pRootFolder.CID 704153 (#1 of 1): Resource leak in object (CTOR_DTOR_LEAK) [select issue]    1. alloc_new: Allocating memory by calling "new ZipPackageFolder(this->m_nFormat, this->m_bAllowRemoveOnInsert)".    2. var_assign: Assigning: "this->m_pRootFolder" = "new ZipPackageFolder(this->m_nFormat, this->m_bAllowRemoveOnInsert)".    3. ctor_dtor_leak: The constructor allocates field "m_pRootFolder" of "ZipPackage" but the destructor and whatever functions it calls do not free it. 160    m_xRootFolder = m_pRootFolder = new ZipPackageFolder( m_nFormat, m_bAllowRemoveOnInsert ); 161} 162    Yeah, I think its a false positive in coverity which doesn't take the m_xRootFolder into account. Its odd code, but I don't think there's a leak.

Patch Set 3: Fails; I would prefer that you didn't submit thisThe hardest part of this was finding out that X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect was involved, so kudos to discovering that.The workaround to search the lower levels if a glyph isn't found however is a bit of a bodge, because I don't think we shuold be asking for the wrong glyphs there in the first place. I think http://cgit.freedesktop.org/libreoffice/core/commit/?id=98f56121858b4bea54d056a073005a10648785c6 should work instead.In MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect we loop through each fallback font and union each level's GetBoundRect to get the result, which seems reasonable, except that for each level that's means a call to SalLayout::GetBoundRect which calls X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect.Those sublevels SalLayouts don't know that they are sublevels so they never set the level bits on their glyphs. Which results in X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect always searching for that glyph in the level 0 font, so there's a mismatch between the font the SalLayout's are created to use and the font that gets used.Now, SalLayout::GetBoundRect is a fairly simple thing, it just calls GetNextGlyphs 1 by 1 and X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect on the result of that.  So I *think* that if we remove the specialized MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect in favour of the default implementation, then because MultiSalLayout::GetNextGlyphs is specialized to do-the-right-thing and set up the glyph ids correctly, then we bubble the ids down to X11SalGraphics::GetGlyphBoundRect correctly to get it to use the right font and we get the correct bounding size.

Patch Set 3: AbandonedI agree using MultiSalLayout::GetNextGlyphs is right way to fix this bug . I didn't remove MultiSalLayout::GetBoundRect  because i thought removing it might break something else.Thanks for reviewing patch

Patch Set 2: Do not submitThanks for tackling this issue ! I have a few comments however:It seems to me that using isalpha / isprint on string characters like this is a particularly horrible way to achieve this :-)To copy/paste a similar chunk of text twice like that is rather poor style - in programming for maintainability the aim is always to minimise the number of new lines we add: to maximise the sharing of lines of code etc.As such - I'd really strongly prefer as much of the if (rtl) { } cases to be shared with the non-rtl cases - can we not setup variables that alter the order of iteration / layout placement / rendering in advance and then use them in a shared block later ?When we do:+            // this code are for reverse the number of sildes in TitleThe title we have there seems to come from:void PresenterPaneBase::PaintBorder (const awt::Rectangle& rUpdateBox)...            mxBorderPainter->paintBorder(                mxPaneId->getResourceURL(),                mxBorderCanvas,                aLocalBorderBox,                rUpdateBox,                msTitle);msTitle - can we not translate translate and/or generate that msTitle (SetTitle?) in the first instance ?Is that created from a template in:void PresenterController::UpdatePaneTitles (void)if so - we should fix it there in just one place :-)That template prolly comes from the (localised?) configuration and just needs changing there ?Anyhow - thanks again for looking at this - with a few tweaks (as above) I think we can make it a lot sweeter.Thanks !

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisIn general, such ifdeffed-out code should not be removed just blindly, but one should check for how long it has been ifdeffed out, and whether there is any comment indicating it is soemthing a still active developer intends to get back to, etc.In this case, I think this code might well be useful, if only we had somebody who was working on this part of the code and was interested in this self-check functionality.(Personally I have no idea what a "job" or "job URL" is.)There is a comment in joburl.cxx that says: "It's used for internal purposes only and never a part of a legal product. Use it for testing and debug only!" so I think it's clear that the intent is that you #define ENABLE_COMPONENT_SELF_CHECK only in your own work copy while working on this code, and that such a #define never gets into version control.Now, another question is then whether we have anybody who knows what this code does, and is interested in debugging and developing it. Would it be better to test DBG_UTIL instead of ENABLE_COMPONENT_SELF_CHECK, to at least make sure the code still compiles (in a --enable-dbgutil build) and doesn't break at run-time?SOme discussion on the mailing list needed IMHO.

Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit thisHi Mathias,first thanks for your patch. It is great start; Well, it does some non-standard things. I suggest to re-shufle it a bit :-)1. You already mentioned that you were unsure about    downloading the files inside configure. I suggest to   do it using the download script.   You might already see the many @FILENAME@ entries in   ooo.lst.in. They are optional. If you do not define such    variable in configure, it will be empty in the generated    ooo.lst file and it will not be downloaded.2. If you use download, it will get the files into the   $TARFILE_LOCATION instead of $SRC_ROOT/moz/zipped.      I suggest to modify the related makefiles in "moz"    module to find the .zip archives in $TARFILE_LOCATION   Note that this approach follows the current trends.   In the past, we copied many 3rd party tarballs into   the related build subdirectories. We do not longer   do it. We already updated most makefiles to unpack the    tarballs directly from the $TARFILE_LOCATION.   3. I suggest to do not copy the dlls in configure because    it is not typical. Instead, I suggest to define variables   that will point to the files. Then you could copy the   files in the makefile that need to use the dlls.4. Please, do not remove the TABs from configure.in from    lines 4469-4515. These lines are copied into "Makefile"    that is later tested. TABs are important in Makefiles,   so your change breaks this test.Thanks a lot for working on it. Feel free to ask if you are in doubts.
